questions.text: A 17-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for the evaluation of irregular menstrual bleeding. Menses have occurred at 60- to 90-day intervals since menarche at the age of 12 years. Her last menstrual period was 4 weeks ago. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms consistently. She reports that she currently has no desire to have children. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 85 kg (187 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Examination shows scattered pustules on the forehead and oily skin. There is coarse hair on the chin and upper lip. Fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 190 mg/dL. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Letrozole is a first-line treatment for women with PCOS who wish to conceive. This medication decreases estrogen levels, which are increased in patients with PCOS due to increased aromatization of androgens. This effect can result in the regulation of folliculogenesis and subsequent ovulation. However, since this young patient currently has no desire to conceive, increasing her fertility is not warranted at this point.

B) INCORRECT:

Danazol is an androgen agonist used in patients with endometriosis or fibrocystic breast disease because of its antigonadotropic (decreasing luteinizing hormone levels and follicle-stimulating hormone levels) and antiestrogenic effects. In PCOS, however, androgen levels are typically increased, which is why antiandrogens (e.g., spironolactone) rather than androgen agonists are used to improve symptoms of hyperandrogenism if the first-line treatment is contraindicated or does not yield the desired effects.

C) INCORRECT:

Gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists, such as leuprolide, can suppress or stimulate the release of luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone, depending on the manner of administration (i.e., continuous or pulsatile). While the pulsatile use of leuprolide is indicated for certain causes of infertility, it is not indicated in PCOS. Continuous administration of GnRH agonists may be used to suppress androgen production in patients with PCOS. However, additional therapy with estrogen and progestin is necessary to prevent symptoms of premature ovarian failure, making these drugs a costly and complicated treatment option that is not routinely indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Clomiphene citrate is a first-line pharmacotherapy in patients with PCOS who have a desire to conceive. This medication increases the secretion of luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone, thereby stimulating ovulation. Although infertility due to oligoovulation or anovulation is one of the main concerns in patients with PCOS, this young woman currently has no desire to get pregnant, which is why pharmacotherapy should focus on relieving symptoms instead.

E) INCORRECT:

Metformin is used to treat type 2 diabetes mellitus and is initiated at the time of diagnosis in addition to lifestyle modifications for weight loss. In patients without symptoms of hyperglycemia (e.g., polyuria), diagnosis of type 2 diabetes mellitus requires ≥ 2 abnormal test results for hyperglycemia. A single random elevated plasma glucose measurement of 190 mg/dL is insufficient for the diagnosis in asymptomatic patients and further workup is required before prescribing metformin for glycemic control.

In addition, metformin is used in patients with PCOS and decreased insulin sensitivity to improve menstrual irregularities, metabolic outcomes, and weight loss. However, metformin monotherapy is only used in PCOS as a second-line treatment for menstrual irregularities in patients with contraindications for the first-line options, which this patient does not have. Finally, metformin may be used as an adjunct to first-line pharmacotherapy, which this patient has not yet received, to address metabolic comorbidities.

F) CORRECT:

A combination oral contraceptive pill (COCP) containing ethinylestradiol and progestin is the first-line pharmacotherapy for patients with PCOS who currently do not wish to conceive. COCPs help regulate the menstrual cycle and, because of antiandrogenic effects, relieve symptoms of hyperandrogenism. In addition, progestin decreases the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and cancer, which are possible complications of PCOS (due to the increased levels of estrogen from aromatization of androgens). Besides pharmacotherapy, weight loss is the mainstay of treatment because obesity and the associated insulin resistance play an important role in the pathophysiology of PCOS.

Metformin may be used as an add-on to COCPs and lifestyle modifications to address metabolic comorbidities (e.g., impaired insulin sensitivity). Monotherapy with metformin may be considered as a second-line treatment for menstrual irregularity in patients unable to take or tolerate COCPs.

G) INCORRECT:

This patient with obesity (BMI of 31 kg/m2) had a single random plasma glucose of 190 mg/dL, which suggests impaired insulin sensitivity, a common feature of patients with PCOS. Decreased insulin sensitivity leads to hyperinsulinism, which exacerbates hyperandrogenism as a result of increased ovarian androgen production, decreased sex hormone-binding globulin, and the resulting increase in free testosterone. Since insulin therapy would further increase the patient's insulin levels and worsen insulin resistance rather than decrease it, it is not beneficial in the treatment of PCOS.
questions.hint: This patient presents with oligomenorrhea and symptoms of hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne vulgaris). These features together with obesity and decreased insulin sensitivity (as evidenced by elevated blood glucose levels) suggest polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician because menarche has not yet occurred. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is 162 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 80 kg (176 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Breast and pubic hair development is Tanner stage 4. She also has oily skin, acne, and hyperpigmentation of the intertriginous areas of her neck and axillae. The remainder of the examination, including pelvic examination, shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) can cause primary amenorrhea, as it causes development failure of the female internal reproductive structures in utero. However, patients with AIS will have scant pubic hair, and pelvic examination will show a vagina that ends in a blind pouch without a cervix. This patient's Tanner stage 4 pubic hair and normal pelvic examination are not consistent with AIS.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum prolactin levels (due to a prolactinoma) can inhibit Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) secretion, resulting in anovulation and amenorrhea. Patients with large prolactinomas usually have symptoms of mass effect (e.g., bitemporal hemianopsia, headache), which this patient lacks. Hyperprolactinemia would also not explain this patient's hyperandrogenism or insulin resistance.

C) INCORRECT:

XO chromosomal abnormality is the cause of Turner syndrome, which is one of the most common etiologies of primary amenorrhea (due to gonadal dysgenesis). However, this patient does not have any of the dysmorphic features of Turner syndrome (e.g., short stature, webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, low hairline) that would suggest this diagnosis. Furthermore, Turner syndrome is not associated with hyperandrogenism or insulin resistance.

D) INCORRECT:

Müllerian agenesis can manifest with primary amenorrhea (due to lack of uterine development) with normal secondary sexual characteristics (due to functional ovaries). However, pelvic examination would show vaginal atresia. Furthermore, this patient's hyperandrogenism and insulin resistance suggests a hormonal imbalance as the cause of her amenorrhea rather than a congenital malformation.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with PCOS have hyperinsulinemia, which is thought to cause increased androgen production by theca cells and increased pituitary LH secretion. Hyperandrogenism and disrupted LH/FSH balance, resulting in elevated LH:FSH ratio, impair follicle maturation, preventing ovulation and progesterone release from the corpus luteum. As a result, there is only estrogen-driven endometrial proliferation (proliferative phase) without a progesterone-driven secretory phase. Without regular shedding of the endometrium, the endometrium can become thick and unstable, resulting in irregular, heavy uterine bleeding, and/or primary amenorrhea. Furthermore, unopposed estrogen-driven endometrial proliferation increases the risk for endometrial hyperplasia and type 1 endometrial cancer.

First-line treatment includes lifestyle modifications to treat obesity if applicable (goal BMI < 25 kg/m2) and, for patients who do not wish to conceive, oral contraceptives to regulate menstrual periods, or, in patients who do wish to conceive, pharmacological induction of ovulation (e.g., with letrozole or clomiphene).
Image Description:

In polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), peripheral insulin resistance (e.g., due to obesity) causes hyperinsulinemia. Hyperinsulinemia stimulates androgen production in cells of the ovarian theca interna. Levels of free androgens are further increased by reduced sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) production in the liver. Hyperandrogenemia stimulates LH release from the anterior pituitary gland, resulting in a disruption of LH/FSH balance and, consequently, impaired follicle maturation. LH/FSH balance is further impaired by increased GnRH pulsatility in the hypothalamus and the conversion of androgens to estrogen in adipose tissue.

F) INCORRECT:

Imperforate hymen can cause primary amenorrhea. However, patients usually experience monthly abdominal pain from the buildup of menstrual blood, and pelvic examination may show hematocolpos whereas this patient's pelvic examination was normal. Moreover, this patient's hyperandrogenism and insulin resistance suggest a hormonal imbalance rather than an outflow tract obstruction.

G) INCORRECT:

Elevated β-hCG levels would suggest pregnancy, which is a common cause of amenorrhea. Although a pregnancy test should be performed in any sexually active female with amenorrhea, this patient's hyperandrogenism and insulin resistance suggest PCOS, which can cause chronic anovulation and infertility.

H) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum TSH levels (due to hypothyroidism) can cause amenorrhea and obesity. However, this patient does not have any other signs of hypothyroidism (e.g., fatigue, muscle weakness, cold intolerance, bradycardia, constipation). Furthermore, hypothyroidism would not explain this patient's hyperandrogenism or insulin resistance.

I) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum cortisol levels would suggest Cushing syndrome, which can cause primary amenorrhea, hyperandrogenism, and insulin resistance. However, this patient does not have any other features of Cushing syndrome (e.g., striae, buffalo hump, central obesity with wasting of extremities, hypertension). Moreover, Cushing syndrome is a rarer cause of amenorrhea, hyperandrogenism, and insulin resistance than PCOS, and cortisol levels in PCOS are usually normal.
questions.hint: Primary amenorrhea in an adolescent with features of hyperandrogenism (acne, oily skin), features of insulin resistance (obesity, benign acanthosis nigricans), and normal pubertal changes of the breast and pubic hair is highly suggestive of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of irregular menstrual bleeding. Menses have occurred at 45-to-90-day intervals since menarche at the age of 15 years. Her last menstrual period was 5 weeks ago. The patient reports that she was too embarrassed to discuss this issue with anyone until now. Over the past two years, she has been unable to become pregnant despite having unprotected sexual intercourse with her husband on a regular basis. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 90 kg (198 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows oily skin and severe facial acne. There is abnormal pigmented hair on the upper lip and around both nipples. The patient wishes to have children. In addition to recommending lifestyle modifications, which of the following is most appropriate to treat this patient's infertility?

choices.text: In vitro fertilization with patient's oocyte
In vitro fertilization with donor oocyte

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In vitro fertilization should be suggested to this patient if first-line and second-line treatment options, e.g., weight loss and ovulation induction with medical therapy, do not provide the desired results. This patient has not yet received any treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

In vitro fertilization with oocyte donation is used to achieve pregnancy in women with a lack of viable oocytes, including those with Turner syndrome, those of advanced reproductive age, and cancer survivors. This patient's presentation suggests PCOS. Considering that her own oocytes are likely viable, donor oocytes would not be the next step in management.

C) INCORRECT:

Progesterone is a steroid hormone that prepares the uterus for implantation and maintains pregnancy. It can be given in cases of recurrent pregnancy loss due to a luteal phase defect. This patient presents with PCOS and has an anovulatory cycle. Therefore, the next steps should be aimed at ovulation induction.

D) INCORRECT:

Bromocriptine is used in women with anovulatory infertility due to hyperprolactinemia, which can cause oligomenorrhea and infertility but would not explain this patient's hirsutism. Moreover, she lacks other common symptoms of hyperprolactinemia, such as galactorrhea and loss of libido.

E) CORRECT:

Letrozole for ovulation induction is a first-line pharmacotherapy for patients with PCOS who wish to conceive. By inhibiting aromatase, letrozole reduces estrogen production, stimulating FSH secretion and thus inducing ovulation. Letrozole is associated with higher live birth rates than clomiphene citrate, another first-line treatment option for ovulation induction in patients with PCOS. Although letrozole is not FDA-approved for this indication, multiple studies have demonstrated its effectiveness and safety, and it is widely used off-label.

Obesity can contribute to increased estrogen secretion and hyperinsulinemia, which are the underlying causes of LH and FSH imbalances that lead to impaired follicle maturation and consequent oligoovulation or anovulation. Therefore, patients with obesity should be advised on lifestyle modifications aimed at weight loss. In patients with insulin resistance, metformin may be added to the treatment regimen.

F) INCORRECT:

Gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists (e.g., leuprolide) lead to a downregulation of the pituitary gland's release of gonadotropins to prevent premature ovulation. Leuprolide can be used prior to an in vitro fertilization (IVF) cycle with controlled ovarian stimulation. In patients with PCOS, IVF in addition to leuprolide therapy should be considered if first-line and second-line treatment options, such as weight loss and ovulation induction with medical therapy, do not provide the desired results. However, this woman has not yet been treated with first-line or second-line treatment options.
questions.hint: This patient presents with oligomenorrhea, symptoms of hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne vulgaris), and infertility. Together with obesity, these features suggest polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a dark discoloration of the skin on her neck. She attributes the skin changes to a necklace she recently bought at a thrift shop. The darkening occurred gradually over the past 2 months and is accompanied by skin thickening. She has peptic ulcer disease. Menses occur at irregular 35- to 60-day intervals and last for 9 days with heavy flow. Menarche was at the age of 14 years and her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She is sexually active with her husband and they do not use contraception. The patient's only medication is cimetidine. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 91 kg (200 lb); BMI is 34 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows velvety, hyperpigmented patches in the axillae, the inframammary fold, and around the neck. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Diffusely enlarged thyroid gland on ultrasonography of the neck
Pituitary tumor on MRI of the head
Atrophic adrenal glands on CT scan of the abdomen
Malignant glandular cells on gastric biopsy
Polycystic ovaries on ultrasonography of the pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A diffusely enlarged thyroid gland on ultrasonography of the neck would be expected in patients with thyroid disorders such as Graves disease or Hashimoto thyroiditis. Hashimoto thyroiditis usually leads to clinical hypothyroidism, which may manifest with obesity and menstrual irregularities. However, the absence of additional features of hypothyroidism in this patient, such as fatigue, cold intolerance, dry skin, hair loss, loss of appetite, and constipation, makes a thyroid disorder unlikely. Furthermore, acanthosis nigricans is only rarely seen in patients with hypothyroidism.

B) INCORRECT:

Pituitary adenomas may produce prolactin (leading to hyperprolactinemia), growth hormone (leading to acromegaly or gigantism), thyroid-stimulating hormone (leading to secondary hyperthyroidism), or adrenocorticotropic hormone (leading to Cushing syndrome). Cushing syndrome is a possible cause of acanthosis nigricans. However, in addition to obesity and irregular menstrual cycles, patients typically present with easily bruisable skin, neuropsychological symptoms (e.g., lethargy, depression, sleep disturbance, or psychosis), muscle weakness, and, most importantly, hypertension.

C) INCORRECT:

Elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels are a laboratory finding characteristic of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). The nonclassic form, which is more common, typically has a late onset, manifesting during late childhood or later. Clinical findings in affected adolescents include irregular menstrual cycles. However, CAH is not associated with acanthosis nigricans.

D) INCORRECT:

Atrophic adrenal glands are typically seen on an abdominal CT scan in cases of autoimmune primary adrenal insufficiency. This disorder typically manifests with hypotension, weight loss, anorexia, lethargy, intestinal complaints (nausea, vomiting, and/or diarrhea), loss of axillary and pubic hair, and hyperpigmentation due to increased production of melanocyte-stimulating hormone. Although this patient has hyperpigmented skin lesions, the hyperpigmentation in adrenal insufficiency is typically diffuse and involves areas that are not normally exposed to sunlight (e.g., palm creases, mucous membrane of the oral cavity). Since the patient has no further signs of adrenal insufficiency besides skin lesions, atrophy of the adrenal glands would be an unlikely finding on abdominal CT scan.

E) INCORRECT:

Malignant cells of glandular origin on a biopsy specimen of the stomach confirm the diagnosis of gastric adenocarcinoma. The patient has peptic ulcer disease, which is a risk factor for gastric cancer. Gastrointestinal malignancies, especially gastric adenocarcinoma, are associated with malignant acanthosis nigricans, which is a paraneoplastic syndrome. While both the benign and malignant form of acanthosis nigricans manifest with velvety, hyperpigmented skin thickening, the paraneoplastic syndrome is characterized by rapid onset, a verrucous or papulous surface, and involvement of atypical sites (e.g., palms, soles, or mucous membranes), which is not the case in this patient. Moreover, the patient is young and has no signs of gastrointestinal malignancy, such as weight loss, anemia, abdominal pain, early satiety, nausea or vomiting, dysphagia, hematemesis, or melena. In addition, her irregular menstrual period and infertility could not be explained by this diagnosis.

F) CORRECT:

Polycystic ovaries on pelvic ultrasound are the characteristic finding of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and part of the Rotterdam diagnostic criteria. Clinical features of PCOS include obesity, features of anovulation (e.g., irregular menstrual cycles, menorrhagia), features of hyperandrogenism (e.g., hirsutism, acne vulgaris), and acanthosis nigricans. The typical skin findings of acanthosis nigricans (hyperpigmented patches in intertriginous and/or nuchal areas) may rarely transform into itching, papillomatous, poorly-defined efflorescences, a finding which is more common in acanthosis nigricans caused by malignancy.
questions.hint: Patches of velvety hyperpigmentation in intertriginous and nuchal areas are consistent with acanthosis nigricans.

questions.text: A 19-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician because of irregular heavy menstrual bleeding since menarche at the age of 16 years. Menses occur at irregular 15- to 45-day intervals and last 7 to 10 days. She has also noted increased hair growth on her face. She has acne vulgaris treated with topical retinoids. Her 70-year-old grandmother has breast cancer. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (181 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Pelvic examination shows copious cervical mucus and slightly enlarged irregular ovaries. If left untreated, this patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Choriocarcinoma is a rare type of gestational trophoblastic disease that only develops after fertilization and implantation of the oocyte. This patient with PCOS actually has a lower risk of developing choriocarcinoma, as chronic anovulation is a hallmark of PCOS, which renders the patient infertile.

B) CORRECT:

In the normal menstrual cycle, estrogen-driven endometrial proliferation (proliferative phase) is opposed by a progesterone-driven secretory phase. Chronic anovulation in PCOS results in prolonged estrogen exposure of the endometrium unopposed by progesterone, which increases the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and endometrial carcinoma. Endometrial carcinoma is the most common cancer of the female genital tract in the US. This malignancy primarily affects postmenopausal women (peak incidence at 65–74 years) and abnormal uterine bleeding is the main symptom, with later stages manifesting with pelvic pain, a palpable abdominal mass, and weight loss.

C) INCORRECT:

Thyroid lymphoma is a complication of Hashimoto thyroiditis, which is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in the US. Although hypothyroidism would explain this patient's obesity and menstrual irregularities, the absence of additional features, such as fatigue, cold intolerance, dry skin, hair loss, loss of appetite, and constipation, make a thyroid disorder unlikely. Hypothyroidism would also not cause this patient's hirsutism, cystic acne, and enlarged irregular ovaries.

D) INCORRECT:

Cervical cancer is strongly associated with human papillomavirus infection and the incidence and mortality of cervical cancer in developed countries have significantly declined since the introduction of routine Pap smear screening. There is insufficient evidence to confirm that PCOS is associated with an increased risk of cervical cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Osteoporosis most commonly affects postmenopausal women due to a decline in the protective effect of estrogen on bone after menopause. PCOS may be associated with a decrease in bone density and an increased risk of osteoporosis, but another complication is more likely.

F) INCORRECT:

The catabolic effect of hypercortisolism on protein metabolism in Cushing syndrome can result in muscle atrophy and weakness that is most pronounced in the proximal muscles. Cushing syndrome can also manifest with obesity, hirsutism, acne, and irregular menstrual cycles. However, this patient has no other characteristic features of Cushing syndrome (e.g., thinning skin, hyperpigmentation in sun-exposed areas, sleep disturbance, depression, and hypertension). PCOS is not associated with an increased risk of proximal myopathy.

G) INCORRECT:

Although PCOS is associated with prolonged estrogen exposure (due to anovulatory cycles and nulliparity), which is a known risk factor for the development of breast cancer, studies were unable to confirm an increased risk of breast cancer in patients with PCOS.
questions.hint: Hyperandrogenic anovulation (as evidenced by delayed menarche, irregular menses, hirsutism, and acne) and obesity are characteristic of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of irregular menstrual bleeding. Menses have occurred at 30- to 90-day intervals since menarche at the age of 12 years. Her last menstrual period was 6 weeks ago. She is sexually active with her husband, and they do not use condoms. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 78 kg (161 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows oily skin and severe acne on the face. There is dark hair on the upper lip and around both nipples. Laboratory studies show:


Follicle-stimulating hormone
20 mIU/mL


Luteinizing hormone
160 mIU/mL


Testosterone
4.1 nmol/L (N < 3.5)


A urine pregnancy test is negative. Given this patient's condition, she should be screened for which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cushing syndrome can cause osteoporosis and often manifests with hirsutism and oligomenorrhea, as seen in this patient. However, other important clinical features of hypercortisolism, such as central obesity and hypertension, are absent. This patient's laboratory findings indicate PCOS, which is not associated with osteoporosis.

B) INCORRECT:

The risk for developing metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) is thought to be increased in patients with PCOS; however, there is a lack of consensus in the guidelines regarding screening for MASLD in patients with increased risk. In addition, screening may be unreliable, as liver function tests may be normal in patients with MASLD.

C) INCORRECT:

The risk for endometrial cancer is thought to be increased in PCOS because of the effects of estrogen on the endometrium alongside decreased progesterone levels due to anovulation. However, routine screening for endometrial cancer in premenopausal patients with PCOS is not recommended, as the benefit of screening in this population is uncertain.

D) INCORRECT:

The risk for ovarian cancer may be elevated in patients with PCOS. However, the association between PCOS and ovarian cancer is not well established, and therefore routine screening in patients with PCOS is not currently recommended. Patients with PCOS and additional risk factors for ovarian cancer (e.g., personal or family history of ovarian, breast, tubal, or peritoneal cancer) may be offered genetic testing (e.g., for BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations, Lynch syndrome).

E) CORRECT:

PCOS is commonly associated with metabolic syndrome, which can manifest with dyslipidemia and insulin resistance. A lipid panel and an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) should therefore be performed at the time of diagnosis of PCOS. If an OGTT cannot be performed, fasting glucose or hemoglobin A1C may be measured instead. An assessment for obstructive sleep apnea should also be performed in addition to calculating BMI and measuring blood pressure. Patients should also be screened for anxiety, depression, and sexual dysfunction.

Transvaginal ultrasound may be performed to identify cystic follicles and assess ovarian volume but is not required to establish the diagnosis of PCOS if ovulatory dysfunction and hyperandrogenism are present.
questions.hint: This patient's oligomenorrhea, features of hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne vulgaris, elevated testosterone), and elevated LH:FSH ratio (≥ 2:1) indicate polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to physician for an annual health maintenance examination. She feels well. She is 155 cm (5 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (174 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Examination shows a skin rash over both axillae. A photograph of her left axilla is shown. This patient's skin finding is most likely associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Niacin deficiency causes pellagra, which manifests with a symmetrical, thickened, and hyperpigmented rash. However, the rash typically occurs in areas of the skin exposed to the sunlight (e.g., face, neck, hands) rather than in the axillae, as seen here. Moreover, further symptoms of pellagra, such as vomiting, diarrhea, atrophic glossitis, and neurological symptoms are absent in this patient. Niacin deficiency is not associated with acanthosis nigricans.

Pellagra and acanthosis nigricans can both manifest with a collar around the neck; also referred to as Casal necklace in the case of pellagra. However, the skin in niacin deficiency looks sun-burnt rather than velvety as seen here.
Image Description:

There are symmetrical, hyperpigmented, hyperkeratotic plaques on sun-exposed areas of the chest (Casal necklace), shoulders, face, hands, and arms.

This is the typical dermatological manifestation of pellagra. Dermatitis is one of the “4 D's of pellagra” alongside diarrhea, dementia, and death.

B) INCORRECT:

Gastrointestinal malignancies can manifest with acanthosis nigricans. However, if this skin finding occurs in association with a malignancy, such as paraneoplastic syndrome, it is characterized by rapid onset, a verrucous or papulous surface, and involvement of atypical sites (e.g., palms, soles, or mucous membranes), which is not the case in this patient. Moreover, malignant acanthosis nigricans is associated with gastric adenocarcinoma, not gastric malignant lymphoma. Lastly, gastric cancer is rare in young adults and this woman has no signs of gastrointestinal malignancy such as weight loss, anemia, abdominal discomfort, or melena.
Image Description:

Hyperpigmentation, hyperkeratosis, and numerous skin tags (papillomatosis) are visible on the right axilla.

These findings are consistent with acanthosis nigricans.

C) INCORRECT:

Primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison disease) presents with hyperpigmented skin lesions caused by the stimulant effects of excess ACTH on the melanocytes which produce melanin (bronze disease). Unlike the skin finding in this patient, the hyperpigmentation in Addison disease is typically generalized and often involves the palm creases or oral mucosa. Instead of obesity, patients with Addison disease present with weight loss and anorexia due to hypocortisolism. Lastly, the absence of other symptoms such as hypotension and intestinal complaints (nausea, vomiting, and/or diarrhea), make Addison disease unlikely.

D) CORRECT:

Acanthosis nigricans is commonly seen in disorders characterized by insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia (e.g., polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), obesity, diabetes mellitus, acromegaly). Elevated levels of insulin stimulate keratinocyte and dermal fibroblast proliferation via interaction with insulin-like growth factor 1, resulting in epidermal hyperplasia and plaque-like lesions. In addition, insulin resistance in PCOS is responsible for hyperandrogenism (leading to acne, hirsutism) and anovulation (causing amenorrhea and impaired fertility).

Similar skin changes can be caused by obesity alone, in which case the disorder is referred to as pseudoacanthosis nigricans.

E) INCORRECT:

Hashimoto thyroiditis usually leads to clinical hypothyroidism, which often presents with obesity and skin abnormalities. However, findings typically include dry, cold, pale, and scaly skin rather than the skin lesion described in this patient. Furthermore, the absence of additional features of hypothyroidism such as fatigue, hair loss, constipation, and/or goiter make Hashimoto thyroiditis unlikely. Hashimoto thyroiditis is not commonly associated with acanthosis nigricans.

F) INCORRECT:

Pregnancy is associated with hyperpigmentation due to increased melanocyte-stimulating hormone produced by the placenta. Although the axillae may be affected, hyperpigmentation of the linea alba, the nipples, areola, and the face (i.e., melasma) are far more common. Moreover, the hyperpigmented macules and patches often seen during pregnancy are not thickened and velvety as seen here. Pregnancy is not associated with acanthosis nigricans.
Image Description:

Hyperpigmented brown, irregularly shaped patches are visible on both sides of the upper and lower cutaneous lip.

These features are characteristic of melasma, which typically has a centrofacial distribution.
questions.hint: The picture shows acanthosis nigricans, a skin condition that manifests with thickened, velvety, hyperpigmented plaques and most frequently involves intertriginous sites such as the axillae or the neck.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of infertility. She has been unable to conceive for the past 2 years. Menses occur at 45 to 80-day intervals. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 77 kg (170 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m2. Physical examination shows facial acne and pigmented hair on the upper lip. Serum studies show elevated levels of testosterone and an LH:FSH ratio of 4:1. Treatment with the appropriate drug for this patient's infertility is begun. Which of the following is the primary mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: Activation of ovarian luteinizing hormone receptors

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Activation of pituitary dopamine receptors is the mechanism of action of bromocriptine, which is used in women who suffer from anovulatory infertility due to hyperprolactinemia. Elevated serum prolactin levels inhibit GnRH secretion, resulting in low levels of FSH and LH (hypogonadotropic hypogonadism). Patients would present with anovulation, amenorrhea, galactorrhea, and possibly symptoms of a pituitary macroadenoma (headaches, bitemporal hemianopia). Bromocriptine is not used to treat infertility caused by PCOS.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of endometrial progesterone receptors is the mechanism of action of mifepristone, which is used in conjunction with a prostaglandin analog (e.g., misoprostol) for medical termination of pregnancy. It is not used to treat infertility in PCOS.

C) INCORRECT:

Activation of ovarian luteinizing hormone (LH) receptors is caused by human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) as LH and hCG have a similar molecular structure and share the same receptors. Injectable hCG causes an LH surge that stimulates ovarian follicular maturation and ovulation and is therefore used to induce ovulation in infertile women. However, it is only a second-line treatment in PCOS because of its higher costs and an increased risk of multiple pregnancy.

D) INCORRECT:

Inhibition, not activation of hypothalamic estrogen receptors, is the mechanism of action of clomiphene, a drug for ovulation induction in women with infertility from PCOS. Clomiphene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator that binds to the hypothalamic estrogen receptors, thereby blocking the negative feedback effect of circulating endogenous estradiol. This results in an increase in the pulsatile secretion of GnRH and subsequent increase in both FSH and LH, stimulating ovulation.

E) CORRECT:

Inhibition of granulosa cell aromatase is the mechanism of action of letrozole, which inhibits the conversion of androgens to estrogens and lowers estrogen levels, stimulating FSH and LH secretion and inducing ovulation. Treatment with letrozole leads to higher live birth rates than clomiphene citrate, making it the first-line treatment for individuals with PCOS who wish to conceive.
questions.hint: This patient's oligomenorrhea, clinical and laboratory signs of hyperandrogenemia (facial acne, hirsutism, elevated serum testosterone), and the LH:FSH ratio > 2:1 suggests that her infertility is due to polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). A first-line treatment for women with PCOS pursuing pregnancy is letrozole.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain and hair loss over the past two years. Menarche occurred at the age of 12 years and menses occurred at irregular intervals until she stopped having periods one year ago. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (180 lb); BMI is 30 kg/m2. Physical examination shows a receding hairline and hair loss over the vertex of the head. Serum studies show:


Thyroid-stimulating hormone
2 μU/mL


Luteinizing hormone
32 mIU/mL


Prolactin
11 ng/mL


Urine pregnancy test is negative. Withdrawal bleeding occurs after a progestin challenge test. The most likely cause of amenorrhea in this patient is an increase in production of which of the following hormones?

choices.text: Follicle stimulating hormone in the adenohypophysis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An increase of progesterone in the corpus luteum is seen in early pregnancy (up to ∼ 10 weeks) and is responsible for maintaining the uterine lining. This patient with suspected PCOS would be expected to have a decrease of progesterone, as the corpus luteum fails to form in anovulatory cycles.

B) INCORRECT:

An increase in androgen production in the adrenal glands is a feature of certain subtypes of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (e.g., 21-hydroxylase deficiency, 11-hydroxylase deficiency). Adrenal androgen production is LH-independent. In PCOS, increased androgen production by the ovaries due to increased LH is expected.

C) CORRECT:

PCOS is characterized by hyperinsulinemia (due to peripheral insulin resistance) and/or increased LH secretion by the anterior pituitary. LH and insulin stimulate the theca cells in the ovary to produce androgens, which can cause symptoms such as androgenic alopecia, hirsutism, or acne. The androgens are converted into estrogens by aromatase in adipose tissue. Androgens from the ovary and estrogen from adipose tissue decrease the production of FSH via negative feedback. Consequently, an arrest in antral follicle development occurs and the granulosa cells, which normally produce estrogen, do not develop adequately. The lack of follicular development results in anovulatory cycles (no corpus luteum and no progesterone production), in which the endometrium continuously proliferates under the effect of estrogen from adipose tissue. The bleeding that occurs in PCOS is not true menstrual bleeding, which is caused by progesterone withdrawal at the end of the menstrual cycle, but anovulatory bleeding, in which partial shedding of the hyperplastic endometrium occurs intermittently at irregular intervals because estrogen cannot maintain the proliferating endometrium. In patients with anovulatory cycles, the administration of progesterone would result in differentiation and maintenance of the endometrium, and subsequent withdrawal of progesterone would cause withdrawal bleeding (progestin challenge test).

PCOS is typically a diagnosis of exclusion that is made after other causes of amenorrhea/oligomenorrhea (e.g., hyperthyroidism, hyperprolactinemia, pregnancy) have been excluded. At least 2 of the following 3 criteria should be present for the diagnosis of PCOS: oligo-ovulation or anovulation; clinical or biochemical evidence of hyperandrogenism; polycystic ovaries on ultrasonography (>12 antral follicles in an ovary).
Image Description:

In polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), peripheral insulin resistance (e.g., due to obesity) causes hyperinsulinemia. Hyperinsulinemia stimulates androgen production in cells of the ovarian theca interna. Levels of free androgens are further increased by reduced sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) production in the liver. Hyperandrogenemia stimulates LH release from the anterior pituitary gland, resulting in a disruption of LH/FSH balance and, consequently, impaired follicle maturation. LH/FSH balance is further impaired by increased GnRH pulsatility in the hypothalamus and the conversion of androgens to estrogen in adipose tissue.

D) INCORRECT:

PCOS patients show a decrease, rather than an increase, of FSH. PCOS is the result of disrupted gonadotropin production by the adenohypophysis, in which an elevated LH:FSH ratio > 2:1 is common.

E) INCORRECT:

Dopamine inhibits prolactin secretion. Therefore, a decreased, not increased, production of dopamine in the hypothalamus would lead to oligomenorrhea due to hyperprolactinemia. Moreover, this patient has a normal prolactin level, which implies that a change in dopamine levels is not the mechanism of this patient's amenorrhea.
questions.hint: Weight gain, androgenic alopecia, secondary amenorrhea, and mildly increased follicular-phase LH levels suggest a diagnosis of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of irregular menstrual bleeding. Menarche occurred at the age of 12 years and menses have occurred at 45 to 90-day intervals. Her last menstrual period was 8 weeks ago. She is not sexually active. Serum studies show:


Fasting glucose
178 mg/dL


Fasting insulin
29 mcIU/mL (N = 2.6–24.9)


Luteinizing hormone
160 mIU/mL


Total testosterone

3.2 ng/dL (N = 0.06–1.06)


Serum electrolytes are within the reference range. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Intrasellar mass on cranial contrast MRI

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum beta-HCG levels would indicate pregnancy, which should be ruled out in any woman with secondary amenorrhea. However, this woman is not sexually active, which makes pregnancy highly unlikely. Furthermore, insulin resistance and an elevation in testosterone and LH would not be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

An adrenal tumor in the setting of oligomenorrhea would be suggestive of adrenal adenoma causing primary hypercortisolism (ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome). The high levels of cortisol cause negative feedback on the pituitary and suppress ACTH release, leading to insulin resistance and irregular menstrual cycles, which are present in this patient. However, this patient's elevated LH and duration of symptoms (irregular menses since age 12) makes an adrenal tumor unlikely.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's features (e.g., oligomenorrhea, insulin resistance, elevated testosterone levels) are highly suggestive of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). PCOS is an endocrinological disorder characterized by peripheral insulin resistance with subsequent hyperinsulinemia and excess androgen production from the theca interna cells. PCOS manifests with decreased follicular maturation, which leads to unruptured follicles (e.g., cysts) and anovulation. Transvaginal ultrasound will typically show bilateral, anechoic cysts and ovarian enlargement.

D) INCORRECT:

An intrasellar mass on cranial contrast MRI in the setting of oligomenorrhea would indicate a prolactinoma, a prolactin-producing tumor of the anterior pituitary gland that is usually benign. However, laboratory tests would not show elevated LH and testosterone or insulin resistance. The duration of this patient's symptoms (irregular menses since age 12), moreover, makes a prolactinoma unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum TSH is seen in hypothyroidism. Although hypothyroidism could cause oligomenorrhea, it would not explain the elevated testosterone or signs of insulin resistance seen here. Furthermore, this patient lacks other typical symptoms such as fatigue, bradycardia, cold intolerance, constipation, and weight gain.
questions.hint: This woman with oligomenorrhea has elevated testosterone and LH levels, as well as evidence of insulin resistance (increased fasting glucose and fasting insulin). Hirsutism and acne would be expected on examination.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman comes to the physician because of hair loss on her frontal scalp over the past year. Menses have occurred at irregular 40- to 60-day intervals since menarche at the age of 17 years. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is 162 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 73 kg (158.7 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. Her pulse is 75/min and blood pressure 130/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows scattered pustules on her face and patches of velvety hyperpigmentation on her axilla and groin. Her morning serum cortisol concentration is 18 μg/dL. This patient's condition is most likely associated with increased stimulation of which of the following types of cells?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Excess stimulation of zona fasciculata cells of the adrenal glands by adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) results in secondary hypercortisolism (endogenous Cushing syndrome). This patient's dermatological findings (acne vulgaris, acanthosis nigricans), menstrual irregularities, and overweight are consistent with secondary hypercortisolism. However, her morning serum cortisol concentration is normal, ruling out this diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Leydig cells are androgen-producing testicular cells and are usually not found in the female reproductive tissue. Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors are rare ovarian tumors characterized by the presence of androgen-producing Leydig cells. Although this patient's symptoms of hyperandrogenism (androgenic alopecia, menstrual irregularities, acne vulgaris) are consistent with this diagnosis, the concomitant features of hyperinsulinism (overweight and acanthosis nigricans) indicate polycystic ovary syndrome.

C) CORRECT:

PCOS is characterized by an increase in the secretion of pituitary luteinizing hormone (LH), which stimulates ovarian theca interna cells to produce androgens. The resulting hyperandrogenism accounts for the typical clinical features of PCOS: cutaneous manifestations (hirsutism, androgenic alopecia, and acne vulgaris), anovulation/oligoovulation (often resulting in infertility), and polycystic ovaries on ultrasound. A majority of affected women also have hyperinsulinism and/or insulin resistance, leading to symptoms such as acanthosis nigricans and weight gain.
Image Description:

In polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), peripheral insulin resistance (e.g., due to obesity) causes hyperinsulinemia. Hyperinsulinemia stimulates androgen production in cells of the ovarian theca interna. Levels of free androgens are further increased by reduced sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) production in the liver. Hyperandrogenemia stimulates LH release from the anterior pituitary gland, resulting in a disruption of LH/FSH balance and, consequently, impaired follicle maturation. LH/FSH balance is further impaired by increased GnRH pulsatility in the hypothalamus and the conversion of androgens to estrogen in adipose tissue.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased stimulation of lactotroph cells in the pituitary gland results in hyperprolactinemia, a condition that can manifest with menstrual irregularities. This patient's other symptoms, however, cannot be explained by hyperprolactinemia. Moreover, premenopausal women with hyperprolactinemia typically present with galactorrhea, which is not seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Granulosa cells, which surround the oocytes within the ovarian follicle, are stimulated by follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) to produce estrogens from androgens. Increased stimulation of granulosa cells results in hyperestrogenism, which may manifest with menstrual irregularities. This patient's other symptoms, however, cannot be explained by hyperestrogenism. FSH secretion is relatively decreased in polycystic ovarian syndrome, which this patient presents with.

F) INCORRECT:

Increased stimulation of follicular thyroid cells by elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels can occur because of TSH-producing pituitary tumors. Subsequent secondary hyperthyroidism may cause menstrual irregularities. This patient's other symptoms, however, cannot be explained by hyperthyroidism. Moreover, additional findings such as tachycardia, heat intolerance, weight loss, and goiter would be expected.
questions.hint: Frontal hair loss, menstrual irregularities, overweight, acne vulgaris (scattered facial pustules), and acanthosis nigricans (velvety hyperpigmentation on axilla and groin) suggest polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

questions.text: A 24-year-old nulligravid woman and her husband come to the physician for the evaluation of infertility. She is 161 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 80 kg (176 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Examination shows thinning of the hair on her scalp and dark, coarse hair on her chin. A photograph of an ovary from a 31-year-old patient with the same condition is shown. Which of the following is most likely to be decreased in the serum of the 24-year-old patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The production of testosterone in the ovaries is stimulated by luteinizing hormone (LH). Patients with PCOS typically have elevated LH levels and therefore an increased concentration of testosterone. Decreased testosterone levels are typically seen in conditions that cause hypogonadism (both primary and secondary).

B) INCORRECT:

Fasting insulin concentration would increase rather than decrease because of an increase in pancreatic insulin secretion in response to peripheral insulin resistance, which is a characteristic feature of PCOS. Fasting insulin secretion would be decreased in conditions associated with pancreatic beta-cell destruction such as type 1 diabetes mellitus.

C) INCORRECT:

Normally, estrogens are produced from androgens through the action of aromatase mainly in the granulosa cells and, to a lesser degree, in adipose tissue. In individuals with PCOS, granulosa cells do not develop due to arrested antral follicle development. However, affected individuals also have increased androgen levels, and the peripheral aromatization of androgens in adipose tissue compensates for the lack of granulosa cell activity. Also, individuals with PCOS are often obese and tend to have a higher level of peripheral aromatase activity, so their estrogen levels remain normal or even increase slightly. Conditions associated with decreased estrogen concentration include menopause, ovarian insufficiency, and hyperprolactinemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Androstenedione is produced mainly in the adrenal glands and, to a lesser degree, in the gonads. In patients with PCOS, luteinizing hormone (LH) levels increase. Since LH directly stimulates the secretion of androstenedione in the ovarian theca cells, the androstenedione concentration increases rather than decreases in PCOS.

Androstenedione levels decrease in 17-α-hydroxylase deficiency, a form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) that can manifest in females with infertility, as seen here. However, virilizing features (e.g., androgenic alopecia, hirsutism) would not occur; instead, female patients with this condition would have primary amenorrhea and delayed secondary sexual characteristics, neither of which are reported in this case. Moreover, 17-α-hydroxylase deficiency would not explain the ovarian findings shown in the image.

E) INCORRECT:

Luteinizing hormone (LH) secretion is increased in patients with PCOS; the reason for this increase is not completely understood. LH stimulates theca cells in the ovary to produce androgens, which decrease the production of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) via negative feedback. As a result of increased LH and decreased FSH levels, the LH:FSH ratio is typically increased in patients with PCOS.

F) CORRECT:

The majority of patients with PCOS are obese and have peripheral insulin resistance, which results in hyperinsulinemia. Hyperinsulinemia ultimately leads to a decrease in sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) concentration via two mechanisms. Hyperinsulinemia directly inhibits the production of SHBG in the liver. At the same time, hyperinsulinemia stimulates ovarian theca cells to produce androgens (e.g., androstenedione, testosterone), which in turn also suppress SHBG production. The other important change in PCOS is increased secretion of luteinizing hormone, which also stimulates theca cells to produce androgens. The increase in total androgen levels coupled with an increase in the proportion of free androgen (due to a decrease in SHBG concentration) results in virilization, as seen here. The androgens also decrease follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) by negative feedback. Decreased levels of FSH arrest antral development, causing anovulatory cycles, which prevents progesterone secretion and subsequently causes affected individuals to become infertile.

SHBG production is decreased by insulin, growth hormone, insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1), androgens, and prolactin; production is increased by estrogen and thyroxine. Other causes of decreased SHBG levels are hypothyroidism, acromegaly, hyperprolactinemia, and the use of anabolic steroids.
Image Description:

In polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), peripheral insulin resistance (e.g., due to obesity) causes hyperinsulinemia. Hyperinsulinemia stimulates androgen production in cells of the ovarian theca interna. Levels of free androgens are further increased by reduced sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) production in the liver. Hyperandrogenemia stimulates LH release from the anterior pituitary gland, resulting in a disruption of LH/FSH balance and, consequently, impaired follicle maturation. LH/FSH balance is further impaired by increased GnRH pulsatility in the hypothalamus and the conversion of androgens to estrogen in adipose tissue.
questions.hint: The image shows an ovary with multiple, circularly arranged, brown subcapsular cysts of roughly the same size (“string of pearls” appearance). This finding and the patient's clinical presentation of infertility, high BMI (indicating obesity), and virilization (e.g., androgenic alopecia, hirsutism) are typical of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of persistent acne and excessive facial and chest hair. She initially presented 7 months ago for evaluation of irregular menses that occurred at 28 to 36-day intervals for 8 days with moderate flow and was started on a combined oral contraceptive. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. She is 157 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows excessive hair growth on the upper lip, in the periareolar area, and along the linea alba. Dermatological examination shows comedones and inflammatory papules on the face and back. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator most commonly used for the treatment of breast cancer. It is not indicated for this patient with PCOS and hirsutism.

B) CORRECT:

Spironolactone is an aldosterone receptor antagonist with antiandrogenic properties that is considered one of the most effective second-line treatment options for patients with hirsutism. Spironolactone can be used in patients with hirsutism that have shown minimal to no response after treatment with COCs for at least 6 months or in those who cannot take COCs.

In patients with renal dysfunction, spironolactone should be avoided because it can lead to metabolic and electrolyte imbalances, such as hyperkalemia, hyponatremia, and metabolic acidosis. If used as monotherapy (e.g., in women with contraindications to COCs), spironolactone should be combined with other contraceptive methods since it carries a risk of undervirilization in male fetuses.

C) INCORRECT:

Flutamide is an androgen receptor blocker that can be used to treat hirsutism in patients who showed no improvement with COCs. However, flutamide is generally avoided because of potentially severe adverse effects (e.g., fatal hepatotoxicity). Other (safer) antiandrogenic agents should be considered in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Photoepilation therapy is a direct and permanent hair removal method that may be used for patients with hirsutism. However, photoepilation does not reduce the increased androgen levels in patients with PCOS, which means hair regrowth may occur later on. Finally, other clinical features of hyperandrogenism, e.g., acne, or androgenic alopecia, would still persist in these patients.

E) INCORRECT:

Danazol is a synthetic androgen with antigonadotropic (decreased luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone) and antiestrogenic effects most commonly used for the treatment of endometriosis or fibrocystic breast disease. In PCOS, however, androgen levels are typically increased, which is why antiandrogens, not androgen agonists, should be used to improve this patient's hirsutism.
questions.hint: Clinical hyperandrogenism and menstrual irregularities are diagnostic of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Since this patient's hyperandrogenic features (hirsutism, acne) have not improved after 6 months of treatment with combined oral contraceptives (COCs), an antiandrogenic agent should be considered to relieve her symptoms.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old young woman presents with acne on her face and upper back, as well as persistent increased hair growth on her face and abdomen that has been difficult to control despite electrolysis and tweezing. She has a history of oligomenorrhea, characterized by two to three menses per year since menarche at 14 years of age. She began taking oral contraceptive pills 6 months ago and now has regular menses.
On physical examination, she has a blood pressure of 110/72 mm Hg, a heart rate of 80 beats per minute, and a BMI of 29.5. Her scalp hair shows some bitemporal thinning, and she has diffuse stubble on her upper lip and chin. Examination of her neck reveals scattered skin tags and no acanthosis nigricans. Her abdomen is soft, with thick terminal hair in the lower quadrants, but striae are not present. Her genitourinary examination is normal, with no clitoromegaly.
Laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
138
136–145


Potassium (mEq/liter)
4.2
3.5–5.0


Chloride (mEq/liter)
104

Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)

Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)

5.4

Dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (μg/dL)
598

17-hydroxyprogesterone (ng/dL)
78

Which one of the following medications is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Flutamide is also an antiandrogen agent. However, it is associated with hepatotoxicity at the doses required for clinical efficacy and is therefore not used to treat PCOS.

B) INCORRECT:

Clomiphene can induce ovulation in patients who are trying to conceive, but it is not used for long-term treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Treatment with glyburide is not appropriate in a patient who does not have overt diabetes mellitus, because it poses a risk of hypoglycemia. Glyburide is not effective for managing hirsutism.

D) INCORRECT:

Metformin has been shown to benefit patients with PCOS who have hyperglycemia, infertility, or both, but it is not effective for managing hirsutism.

E) CORRECT:

The diagnosis of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) requires the presence of at least two of the following findings:

• Oligo- or anovulation (usually manifesting as menstrual irregularity)
• Androgen excess
• Polycystic ovaries on ultrasonography OR (in adult patients) elevated antimüllerian hormone levels

The addition of antimüllerian hormone levels as a diagnostic criterion is new as of 2023 and applies only to adults.

Spironolactone, an androgen- and mineralocorticoid-receptor blocker, is effective and safe and is the preferred drug for patients with PCOS who have an elevated testosterone level and persistent hirsutism despite treatment with an oral contraceptive pill.

Key learning point: The most effective treatment for a young woman with polycystic ovary syndrome who is bothered by hirsutism that has persisted despite treatment with an oral contraceptive pill is spironolactone.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman is seen for irregular menses and facial hair growth. Her menarche was at age 13, and her menstrual periods have been regular ever since. During the past 6 months, she has noticed a weight gain of 5 kg associated with irregular periods (menses every 30 to 50 days). In addition, she has noticed facial acne and substantial hair growth on her face, abdomen, and arms during the past 5 months. Her medical history is significant only for overweight; her BMI is 28.7. Her mother has a history of type 2 diabetes.
On examination, her blood pressure is 144/86 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 88 beats per minute. She has substantial amounts of terminal hair growth on her chin, upper lip, both arms, and abdomen. In addition, she has acne on her face and chest. On pelvic examination, her clitoris is enlarged, but she has no adnexal masses.
Laboratory findings are shown in the figure below.



Patient value
Reference range


Thyroid-stimulating hormone (μU/mL)
3.3
0.5–4.7



Testosterone (ng/dL)
330
6–86



Dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (μg/dL)
664
12–535


Prolactin (ng/mL)

Glycated hemoglobin (%)

4.3–5.6


Which one of the following evaluations is most likely to lead to the diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of estrogen and progesterone levels
Imaging of the adrenal glands and the pelvis
Measurement of urinary catecholamine and metanephrine levels

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although hyperprolactinemia, acromegaly, and thyroid dysfunction could cause mild androgen excess, people with those conditions typically present with signs and symptoms that typify them. Thus, imaging the pituitary gland is not indicated in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Measuring estrogen and progesterone levels is not appropriate because the levels of these hormones are likely to be low in the presence of the anovulation associated with this patient’s degree of oligoamenorrhea and would not account for this clinical presentation if elevated.

C) INCORRECT:

Measuring 17-hydroxyprogesterone to check for nonclassical, congenital adrenal hyperplasia is not necessary in this patient, because that condition is usually peripubertal in onset and causes mild, chronic hyperandrogenism (with oligomenorrhea and hirsutism) that gradually increases over a period of several years.

D) CORRECT:

Although the most common cause of irregular menses and hyperandrogenism is polycystic ovary syndrome, that syndrome usually causes only mild elevation of testosterone levels. Androgen-secreting tumors, which are present in only about 0.2% of hyperandrogenic women, cause the rapid development of symptoms and signs of hyperandrogenism, virilization, and very high levels of androgens. The appropriate test for these tumors is imaging of the ovaries and adrenal glands. Dexamethasone suppression testing should also be performed, because the tumor is likely to be secreting cortisol as well.

Key learning point: The rapid onset of virilization in women should prompt an evaluation for androgen-secreting tumors of the ovaries or adrenal glands.

E) INCORRECT:

Urinary metanephrine and catecholamine levels can be ordered in the evaluation for pheochromocytoma, an adrenal tumor that causes severe fluctuations in blood pressure. Although this patient does have one elevated blood pressure reading, there are no other symptoms to suggest pheochromocytoma, such as flushing or headache.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents to discuss an inability to conceive after 12 months of having regular intercourse with her husband without contraception. She reached menarche at age 13 and had irregular periods until she started an oral contraceptive at age 16.
Last year, she stopped the oral contraceptive so that she could try to become pregnant. Her periods resumed within several months but have been irregular in duration and occur every 4 to 6 weeks. She has no other significant medical history and takes no medications. She reports no visual symptoms, headaches, galactorrhea, recent weight gain, voice changes, or muscle weakness.
Her husband is healthy and has two children from a previous marriage. Results of his semen analysis are within the normal range.
On physical examination, the patient has a BMI of 30.1. She has mild scalp hair loss (primarily affecting the crown), mild hirsutism, and acne on her face and chin. Otherwise, her face seems unchanged compared with a driver’s license photo taken 3 years ago. There is no abnormal deposition in the supraclavicular or dorsocervical fat pads. Acanthosis nigricans is noted in the axillae and neck. The patient has no galactorrhea or tenderness on breast examination. Her cardiac, pulmonary, abdominal, and pelvic examinations are unremarkable; she has no striae.
Laboratory evaluation performed on the morning of day 3 of her menstrual cycle yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Prolactin (ng/mL)
10
0–20


Follicle-stimulating hormone (mIU/mL)
6

27
<20–145

Antimüllerian hormone (ng/mL)
10.8

61

A comprehensive metabolic panel is normal, and a pregnancy test is negative.
Which one of the following treatments should be recommended as the most effective agent to increase this patient's fertility?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The most likely cause of this patient’s infertility is polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Diagnosis of PCOS requires the presence of at least two of the following three criteria:

• Irregular menstrual cycles
• Clinical evidence of hyperandrogenism (acne, hirsutism, hair loss) OR elevated blood levels of androgens
• Polycystic ovary morphology on pelvic ultrasound OR (in adults) an elevated level of antimüllerian hormone

In addition, before PCOS is diagnosed, pregnancy and alternative diagnoses should be ruled out. This process involves a thorough history and appropriate laboratory testing, which typically includes evaluation of prolactin, thyroid-stimulating hormone, 17-hydroxyprogesterone level, and day-3 measurement of follicle-stimulating hormone.

This patient fulfills all three criteria for PCOS, and the additional laboratory evaluation rules out other diagnoses.

Treating Infertility in Patients with PCOS

Even modest weight loss in a patient with PCOS might lead to clinically significant improvement in fertility, so this should be attempted before ovulation induction. However, among the interventions listed, letrozole has been shown to increase both ovulation and the rate of live births — and is considered the first-line ovulation-induction agent in patients with PCOS.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial therapy for infertility in a patient with polycystic ovary syndrome is letrozole.

B) INCORRECT:

Because of its cost, in vitro fertilization is generally reserved until after other options have failed.

C) INCORRECT:

Metformin can be used alone to treat anovulation in patients with polycystic ovary syndrome but is less effective than letrozole and is therefore not the most appropriate therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Levothyroxine is not indicated in this case given the patient's normal thyroid-stimulating hormone level.

E) INCORRECT:

Clomiphene was previously considered the agent of choice in this setting, but in a double-blind, randomized trial, women who took letrozole had a significantly higher live-birth rate than those who took clomiphene (27.5% vs. 19.1%). Therefore, even though clomiphene is approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for ovulation induction and letrozole is not, letrozole is now considered the preferred option. Clomiphene may still be considered in individual patients based on their specific circumstances, although it is no longer considered first-line therapy.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman reports that she has had only three “normal” episodes of menstrual bleeding during the past 2 years, with multiple episodes of spotting. She has no other medical problems that she is aware of. She gave birth to a healthy child by spontaneous vaginal delivery 10 years ago and subsequently gained 14 kg in weight. She reports using wax to remove hair on her extremities, lower abdomen, and face.
On examination, she has a BMI of 33 and scattered acne. A pregnancy test is negative.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism can manifest with amenorrhea or oligomenorrhea and heavy menstrual bleeding; however, it is not associated with hyperandrogenism, making it a less likely diagnosis in this case. Nevertheless, guidelines recommend measuring thyroid-stimulating hormone levels in all patients in whom a diagnosis of polycystic ovary syndrome is being considered.

B) CORRECT:

The most likely cause of this patient’s presentation is polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). A diagnosis of PCOS requires that at least two of the following three criteria are fulfilled:

• Irregular menstrual cycles
• Clinical evidence of hyperandrogenism (acne, hirsutism, hair loss) OR elevated blood levels of androgens
• Polycystic ovary morphology on pelvic ultrasound OR (in adults) an elevated level of antimüllerian hormone

This patient has irregular menstrual cycles and clinical hyperandrogenism (hirsutism), making PCOS the most likely diagnosis. Before the diagnosis of PCOS can be confirmed in this patient, alternative diagnoses should be ruled out. This process involves a thorough history and appropriate laboratory testing, which typically includes evaluation of prolactin, thyroid-stimulating hormone, 17-hydroxyprogesterone (17-OHP), and day-3 measurement of follicle-stimulating hormone.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of irregular or absent menstrual periods and hyperandrogenism is polycystic ovary syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Classic congenital adrenal hyperplasia usually manifests in early infancy with adrenal insufficiency and genital ambiguity in females. “Nonclassic” or late-onset congenital adrenal hyperplasia is usually diagnosed at the time of puberty, if not earlier, and can cause hyperandrogenism and oligomenorrhea. Although this diagnosis should be ruled out through measurement of 17-OHP levels, it is much less likely than polycystic ovary syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Cushing syndrome is characterized by upper-body obesity, a rounded face, increased fat around the neck, and relatively slender arms and legs, with other features that include hypertension, striae, proximal myopathy, bruising, and hyperglycemia. Testing for Cushing syndrome is not routine in patients presenting with irregular menstrual periods and hyperandrogenism unless other clinical features suggest this diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

An ovarian teratoma could cause pelvic discomfort depending on its size, but it would not cause signs of androgen excess or oligomenorrhea.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman with a history of polycystic ovary syndrome reports that her menses last 2 weeks or more and occur every 3 to 4 months. She has been unable to become pregnant despite 2 years of regular intercourse with her husband without contraception. She is otherwise healthy. Her husband fathered two children in a previous marriage.
Her gynecologic examination is entirely normal, including secondary sexual characteristics. She has mild acne and hirsutism. Her BMI is 28.
What is the first-line approach to managing this patient's anovulation and infertility?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is often accompanied by infertility and metabolic syndrome.

Historically, clomiphene (a selective estrogen-receptor modulator) has been used for ovulation induction in patients with PCOS. It antagonizes hypothalamic estrogen receptors to increase secretion of endogenous gonadotropins, resulting in ovarian stimulation and ovulation. Clomiphene is approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for this indication and has been shown to be superior to metformin alone to achieve pregnancy with a low rate of multiple births. The combination of clomiphene with an insulin-sensitizing agent (such as metformin) is not clearly superior to clomiphene alone.

Letrozole is an aromatase inhibitor that blocks estrogen synthesis; the reduced estrogen lowers negative feedback and enhances hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian function, resulting in ovulation induction. Letrozole is not FDA-approved for ovulation induction but has been used off-label for this indication for years and is now the preferred first-line treatment for anovulatory infertility in PCOS. A large, double-blind, randomized controlled trial published in 2014 showed that women with PCOS who took letrozole for ovulation induction had a significantly higher live-birth rate than those who took clomiphene (27.5% vs. 19.1%) and also a significantly higher cumulative ovulation rate (61.7% vs 48.3%).

Key learning point: In an anovulatory patient with polycystic ovary syndrome, the first-line medical approach to the treatment of infertility is letrozole.

B) INCORRECT:

If a patient does not become pregnant with initial medical management, additional options such as recombinant gonadotropins and ovarian drilling are appropriate to consider. Synthetic gonadotropins must be used cautiously because patients with polycystic ovary syndrome are more prone to ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Although metformin addresses associated metabolic disease in patients with polycystic ovary syndrome, it has been shown to be inferior to other oral ovulation-induction agents when used alone.

D) INCORRECT:

Intrauterine insemination is used to introduce sperm into the uterine cavity. It is reserved for idiopathic cases of infertility and for cases caused by a cervical etiology or poor sperm count and quality.

E) INCORRECT:

If a patient does not become pregnant with initial medical management, additional options such as recombinant gonadotropins and ovarian drilling are appropriate to consider.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old woman reports irregular menses. She reached menarche at age 12 and has typically had a menstrual period every 60 to 70 days since then, with each one lasting approximately 5 days. It has now been 3 months since her last period. She is not sexually active and has had no galactorrhea. She feels well, exercises regularly, and does not report any recent changes in weight.
Her vital signs are normal, and her BMI is 21.5. Inflammatory acne is evident on her face and back, and a few terminal hairs are evident on the thighs and on the abdominal midline below the umbilicus. The thyroid gland is not enlarged. Abdominal and external genital examinations are normal.
The patient’s mother developed Hashimoto thyroiditis at a young age.
A urine pregnancy test is negative.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). This condition affects up to 10% of women of reproductive age. It is associated with anovulation and abnormal luteinizing hormone secretion, resulting in increased androgen production from the ovaries and adrenal glands. Only some women with PCOS have obesity. PCOS is associated with insulin resistance in the majority of affected patients and is an independent risk factor for the development of type 2 diabetes and metabolic syndrome.

Diagnosis of PCOS requires fulfillment of at least two of the following three criteria:

• Irregular menstrual cycles
• Clinical evidence of hyperandrogenism (acne, hirsutism, hair loss) OR elevated blood levels of androgens. To assess biochemical hyperandrogenism, measurement of free testosterone is recommended, because total testosterone levels may be falsely normal in PCOS due to low sex hormone-binding globulin levels in states of hyperinsulinemia.
• Polycystic ovary morphology on pelvic ultrasound OR (in adults) an elevated level of antimüllerian hormone

In addition, before PCOS is diagnosed, pregnancy and alternative diagnoses should be ruled out, and this would be the next step for this patient. This process involves a thorough history and appropriate laboratory testing, which typically includes evaluation of:

• Prolactin to rule out hyperprolactinemia
• Thyroid-stimulating hormone to rule out thyroid disease
• 17-hydroxyprogesterone to rule out congenital adrenal hyperplasia
• Day-3 follicle-stimulating hormone to rule out primary ovarian insufficiency

Other testing can be helpful in select cases, such as testing for Cushing syndrome in patients with unexplained weight gain or other features of glucocorticoid excess. The ratio of luteinizing hormone to follicle-stimulating hormone may be elevated in PCOS but is not required for diagnosis.

Key learning point: Even in the setting of a normal body weight, the most likely diagnosis in a young woman who presents with oligomenorrhea and hyperandrogenism is polycystic ovary syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Physiologic anovulatory cycles are usually evident only during the first 2 years after menarche.

C) INCORRECT:

Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea is likely to manifest in a young woman with an eating disorder or another chronic disease, and it is generally associated with amenorrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperprolactinemia can manifest with oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea, but it usually does not include symptoms of hyperandrogenism and may be associated with galactorrhea.

E) INCORRECT:

Primary ovarian insufficiency can manifest with oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea, but it is not associated with symptoms of hyperandrogenism. A personal or family history of other autoimmune conditions can increase the risk for developing primary ovarian insufficiency.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl reports irregular menses. She reached menarche at age 12 and, until about a year ago, had menstrual periods every 20 to 40 days, typically lasting for 5 days each. During the past year, however, her periods have occurred sporadically, often more than 3 months apart. She reports no galactorrhea and is not sexually active. She feels well, exercises regularly, and does not report any recent changes in weight. Her family history is significant for Hashimoto thyroiditis in her mother at a young age.
The patient's vital signs are normal, and her BMI is 21.5 (60th percentile). Inflammatory acne is evident on her face and back, and a few terminal hairs are evident on the thighs and the abdominal midline below the umbilicus. The thyroid gland is not enlarged. Abdominal and external genital examinations are normal.
A urine pregnancy test is negative.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Primary ovarian insufficiency can manifest with oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea, but it is not associated with symptoms of hyperandrogenism. A personal or family history of other autoimmune conditions can increase the risk for developing primary ovarian insufficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea is likely to manifest in an adolescent with an eating disorder or another chronic disease, and it is generally associated with amenorrhea.

C) CORRECT:

Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) affects up to 10% of women of reproductive age.
