It is associated with anovulation and abnormal luteinizing hormone secretion, resulting in increased androgen production from the ovaries and adrenal glands. Only some women with PCOS have obesity. PCOS is associated with insulin resistance in the majority of affected patients and is an independent risk factor for the development of type 2 diabetes and metabolic syndrome.

Diagnosis of PCOS in adolescents is based on clinical or biochemical evidence of hyperandrogenism (such as acne or hirsutism) and persistent oligomenorrhea, according to current guidelines from the Endocrine Society and the International PCOS Network. A pelvic ultrasound is not required to confirm a diagnosis of PCOS in adolescents. Other conditions, including prolactin excess and thyroid disease, must be excluded.

In cases of suspected PCOS, it is useful to measure levels of luteinizing hormone, follicle-stimulating hormone, total testosterone, free testosterone, dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and prolactin. PCOS symptoms can be managed with a variety of approaches, including hormonal therapies (such as oral contraceptive pills), spironolactone, or both. Metformin may also be used off-label if there are signs of insulin resistance.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in an adolescent girl who has oligomenorrhea, hyperandrogenism, and a normal body weight is polycystic ovary syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperprolactinemia can manifest with oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea, but it usually does not include symptoms of hyperandrogenism and may be associated with galactorrhea.

E) INCORRECT:

Physiologic anovulatory cycles are usually evident only during the first 2 years after menarche.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl expresses concern about her menstrual periods. She reports that she reached menarche at age 12 and initially had irregular periods. They became regular by age 14, occurring on a monthly basis and lasting 6 to 7 days each, but in the past year, they have become irregular again, occurring every 3 to 4 months and lasting 15 to 20 days at a time. Her periods have always been painless. She also reports that she developed hirsutism this year and gained about 7 kg, changes that she attributes to an increase in her intake of fast food.
She has multiple female relatives with a history of infertility but no other family history of menstrual or endocrine disorders. She reports that she has never been sexually active.
Her vital signs are within normal limits, and her BMI is at the 90th percentile. Physical examination demonstrates facial hair along the upper lip, chin, neck and jawline as well as hair on the abdomen. An external genitourinary examination is unremarkable.
Thyroid tests, a prolactin level, and a 17-hydroxyprogesterone level are all normal.
What testing is most likely to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A brain MRI would be appropriate to evaluate for prolactinoma if prolactin levels had been found to be elevated.

B) INCORRECT:

Measurement of follicle-stimulating hormone levels may be useful for patients with amenorrhea and concerns for primary ovarian insufficiency, but that is not the case with this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

A von Willebrand panel would be appropriate if a bleeding disorder was thought to be the cause of the patient's irregular menses. Menorrhagia is often the presenting symptom for girls with von Willebrand factor (vWf) deficiency. Menses may be excessive in both duration and the amount of bleeding, often starting at menarche. This patient’s menstrual history is not consistent with vWf deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Glycated hemoglobin testing is indicated as screening for diabetes mellitus in patients with a BMI ≥85th percentile, but diabetes is not likely to be the cause of this patient’s menstrual irregularities.

E) CORRECT:

A typical menstrual period lasts 3 to 7 days and involves an average blood loss of 30 to 40 mL. The most common reason for irregular menses in adolescents is anovulation related to immaturity of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian (HPO) axis. Most girls are anovulatory in the first year after menarche, and irregularity of periods during this time is within the range of normal. It takes an average of 18 to 24 months for the HPO axis to mature and for girls to achieve regular ovulatory cycles.

In this case, immaturity of the HPO axis is unlikely to be the cause of the patient's irregular menses, because she is 5 years post-menarche and previously had regular menses. Evaluation for other causes is therefore warranted.

This patient has experienced weight gain and hirsutism in addition to irregular menses, a combination that suggests hyperandrogenism. Although patients with congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) can present similarly to this patient and CAH can be associated with infertility, a normal 17-hydroxyprogresterone level rules out most forms of CAH. Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), which can also cause hyperandrogenism and be associated with infertility, is a more likely diagnosis.

PCOS is a syndrome, and as such, has a constellation of signs and symptoms that are consistent with the diagnosis. The most common clinical findings are as follows:

• Oligo-ovulation or anovulation (e.g., irregular menses)
• Hyperandrogenism (e.g., hirsutism and acne)
• Obesity, insulin resistance, or both
• Polycystic ovaries

For adolescents, irregular menses and hyperandrogenism are needed for the diagnosis, but obesity, insulin resistance, and polycystic ovaries are not. Ultrasound for polycystic ovaries is no longer recommended for diagnosis in adolescents because of its poor specificity.

When PCOS is suspected in a patient with irregular menses, the most appropriate next step is to measure androgen levels, including free and total testosterone, to confirm the diagnosis.

If a PCOS diagnosis is made, additional screening is recommended — specifically, a lipid profile and testing for insulin resistance.

Key learning point: In a patient with suspected polycystic ovary syndrome, the most appropriate diagnostic testing is measurement of androgen levels, including free and total testosterone.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl with a long-standing history of obesity (BMI >95th percentile since infancy) reports unwanted hair on the sides of her face, abdomen, and lower back. She reached menarche at age 12 and reports irregular menses during the past year.
On examination, she has moderate hirsutism and thickened, hyperpigmented skin on the posterior neck.
Laboratory evaluation reveals a mildly elevated total testosterone level via tandem mass spectroscopy and normal levels of prolactin, dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate, follicle-stimulating hormone, estradiol, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and first-morning 17-hydroxyprogesterone. Urine human chorionic gonadotropin testing is negative.
Which one of the following screening tests is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of glutamic acid decarboxylase antibody
Measurement of C peptide with random plasma glucose

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glutamic acid decarboxylase antibody is an islet cell antibody that is often positive in individuals with type 1 diabetes. Given that PCOS is a risk factor for development of type 2 diabetes, autoantibodies are not expected to be present and thus would not be helpful to evaluate in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

Glycated hemoglobin tests and fasting plasma glucose levels are more convenient than a formal 2-hour OGTT, but they are less sensitive and, in the setting of PCOS, will fail to make the correct diagnosis in an unacceptable proportion of patients. This is because in the early stages of abnormal glucose metabolism, the physiologic mechanisms that maintain euglycemia may be able to keep both the fasting blood glucose level and the average blood glucose level (which is assessed using the glycated hemoglobin level) normal.

C) CORRECT:

This patient meets diagnostic criteria for polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Current guidelines from the Endocrine Society and the International Consortium of Pediatric Endocrinology suggest that a diagnosis of PCOS can be made in adolescents when there is both persistent oligomenorrhea and clinical or biochemical evidence of hyperandrogenism, and other possible causes of hyperandrogenism have been excluded. Acne and hirsutism are common manifestations of hyperandrogenism. Hirsutism is defined as excessive thickened hairs in a male pattern of distribution. Biochemical hyperandrogenism is defined as a persistently elevated testosterone level (for an adult female) that is run in a reliable laboratory with well-defined reference ranges.

Because PCOS is associated with a 5- to 10-fold increased risk for type 2 diabetes and prediabetes, screening for these conditions is recommended upon diagnosis of PCOS and should be conducted regularly. The preferred screening approach in patients with PCOS is a 2-hour oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) with a 75-gram glucose load. The diagnostic cutoffs are the same as those used in other populations. See “Interpretation of hyperglycemia tests” table.

Glycated hemoglobin tests and fasting plasma glucose levels are more convenient than a formal 2-hour OGTT, but they are less sensitive and, in the setting of PCOS, will fail to make the correct diagnosis in an unacceptable proportion of patients. This is because in the early stages of abnormal glucose metabolism, the physiologic mechanisms that maintain euglycemia may be able to keep both the fasting blood glucose level and the average blood glucose level (which is assessed using the glycated hemoglobin level) normal. However, the ingestion of glucose during an OGTT creates a homeostatic challenge to euglycemia, and the physiologic mechanisms that were previously able to maintain euglycemia may no longer be adequate; abnormal glucose metabolism may become apparent, and impaired glucose tolerance can be seen. Impaired glucose tolerance is an additional major risk factor for the development of type 2 diabetes and has also been linked to cardiovascular disease, so making this diagnosis is important to allow for early interventions. Therefore, the OGTT is preferred over the more convenient tests because of the additional clinically relevant details on glucose metabolism that it provides. Nevertheless, if a patient with PCOS is unable or unwilling to complete an OGTT, a glycated hemoglobin test or fasting plasma glucose level may be considered.

Given this patient’s obesity and insulin resistance, she is also at increased risk for nonalcoholic fatty liver disease and should therefore undergo screening for this condition. The preferred test is measurement of serum alanine aminotransferase, not liver ultrasound.

Key learning point: The recommended screening test to evaluate for type 2 diabetes in an adolescent with polycystic ovary syndrome is a 2-hour oral glucose tolerance test.

D) INCORRECT:

Given this patient’s obesity and insulin resistance, she is also at increased risk for nonalcoholic fatty liver disease and should therefore undergo screening for this condition. The preferred test is measurement of serum alanine aminotransferase, not liver ultrasound.

E) INCORRECT:

An elevated C-peptide level is suggestive of hyperinsulinemia but is not recommended as a screening test for diabetes.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl presents with concerns about “embarrassing” hair growth on her face. She is very bothered by it, has found temporary hair-removal methods to be frustrating, and says she cannot afford permanent hair-removal options.
She has not been to the clinic for several years. Review of her chart indicates that she reached each stage of puberty at a normal age, including menarche at age 11 years. Her periods have always been irregular, occurring every 50 to 70 days, until she was started on a birth control pill for pregnancy prevention, one year ago by a nurse practitioner in her school health clinic. She is taking a monophasic pill containing 35 μg of ethinyl estradiol and 0.25 mg of norgestimate, and she states that she does not miss any doses. She identifies as female, is heterosexual, and is sexually active.
Her chart indicates no chronic medical problems. She reports no headaches, fatigue, deepening of the voice, breast discharge, or problems with bowel or bladder function. She uses over-the-counter adapalene gel and benzoyl peroxide for acne and is satisfied with their efficacy. Her family history is unremarkable.
Her vital signs are notable for a blood pressure of 135/85 mm Hg and a BMI at the 95th percentile. Physical examination reveals a moderate amount of dark hair above her upper lip and in the beard distribution. She has mild papulopustular acne on her face and acanthosis nigricans on the back of her neck. The rest of the examination, including an external genital examination, is unremarkable.
Several laboratory tests are ordered, but results will not be available for a couple of days.
Which one of the following interventions is most likely to improve this patient’s primary concern?

choices.text: Recommend weight loss through diet and exercise
Discontinue the oral contraceptive pill, and recommend a levonorgestrel intrauterine device
Add spironolactone to the current regimen
Add metformin to the current regimen
Add semaglutide to the current regimen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In patients with PCOS and overweight, recommending lifestyle measures such as diet and exercise, with the goal of weight loss, is important. Weight loss resulting from this intervention could restore regular ovulatory cycles, improve glucose control and lipid profiles, and reduce serum androgen levels. However, it would be unlikely to result in a significant improvement in hirsutism, this patient’s primary concern.

B) INCORRECT:

Switching this patient to a levonorgestrel intrauterine device would not be helpful. Although such devices are very effective at preventing pregnancy, they typically increase menstrual irregularity. Levonorgestrel is a more androgenic progestin, and this treatment would not provide an estrogen component, which is helpful in treating hyperandrogenism.

C) CORRECT:

This patient is likely to have polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), given her history of persistent oligomenorrhea and hirsutism. Diagnosing PCOS in adolescents is often challenging because menstrual cycles can be irregular for a few years following menarche, and some degree of hyperandrogenism is physiologic during puberty. Nevertheless, PCOS may be diagnosed in an adolescent who has persistently abnormal menstrual patterns in addition to clinical or biochemical evidence of hyperandrogenism. Other causes of hyperandrogenism must be excluded, such as nonclassic congenital adrenal hyperplasia, androgen-secreting tumors, hypothyroidism, hyperprolactinemia, and exogenous use of glucocorticoids. Signs of clinical hyperandrogenism include hirsutism, worsening acne, and male-pattern baldness.

In adults, ultrasound findings of multiple cystic follicles is another component of the diagnostic criteria. However, ultrasound is not used to diagnose PCOS in adolescents, because a polycystic appearance of the ovaries in this age group is often normal. Many patients with PCOS also have obesity, signs of insulin resistance, or both — but these elements are not part of the diagnostic criteria.

The standard laboratory workup for an adolescent with possible PCOS includes measurement of human chorionic gonadotropin, serum androgens (total and free testosterone, dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate, and 17-hydroxyprogesterone), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), luteinizing hormone (LH), thyroid hormones, and prolactin. If the patient also has obesity or signs of metabolic syndrome, then measurement of fasting glucose, glycated hemoglobin, and lipids should be added.

Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) are frequently used to treat PCOS because they help to regulate the menstrual cycle and reduce hirsutism and acne. The estrogenic component of a COCP functions to: (1) increase the production of sex-hormone-binding globulin, which binds to testosterone and lowers the level of free (metabolically active) testosterone, and (2) suppress LH, which reduces production of androgens by the ovaries and adrenal glands. Progestins block the androgen receptor and inhibit 5α-reductase activity. Adolescents with PCOS and hirsutism are usually started on a COCP containing 30 μg to 35 μg of ethinyl estradiol and an antiandrogenic or minimally androgenic progestin (such as drospirenone or norgestimate). This patient is already taking an ideal COCP.

If hirsutism is not adequately controlled after 6 months of therapy with a COCP, an antiandrogen may be added. Combination therapy with COCPs and antiandrogens is more effective than either treatment alone. The first-line antiandrogen is spironolactone, which blocks the androgen receptor and reduces testosterone production by blocking enzymes involved in androgen synthesis.

Key learning point: In patients with suspected or confirmed polycystic ovary syndrome who desire pharmacotherapy for hirsutism, combined oral contraceptive pills are first-line therapy, but if the response is insufficient after 6 months, antiandrogen therapy with spironolactone may be added.

D) INCORRECT:

Metformin is an insulin sensitizer used to treat type 2 diabetes and, sometimes, to treat PCOS, particularly in patients with overweight or obesity. Weight loss resulting from this intervention could restore regular ovulatory cycles, improve glucose control and lipid profiles, and reduce serum androgen levels. However, it would be unlikely to result in a significant improvement in hirsutism, this patient’s primary concern.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient may be a candidate for a medication such as semaglutide, a glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist that can assist with weight loss (and treat type 2 diabetes). Weight loss resulting from this intervention could restore regular ovulatory cycles, improve glucose control and lipid profiles, and reduce serum androgen levels. However, it would be unlikely to result in a significant improvement in hirsutism, this patient’s primary concern.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old woman presents for a health maintenance examination at her university health center. She takes no medications and has never been sexually active. She reports no problems with appetite, sleep, bowel movements, urination, or mood. She reached menarche at 13 years of age, but her periods have never been regular, occurring every 40 to 90 days. She smokes a couple of cigarettes each day but does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Her mother has type 2 diabetes and had a heart attack recently, at 55 years of age. Her father has well-controlled hypertension. Her blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg, and her BMI is 24.
On examination, comedones are noted on her forehead, nose, and cheeks (figure). She also has a moderate amount of dark hair above her upper lip, on her chin, and on her lower abdomen. An external genitourinary examination is unremarkable.
A urine sample is negative for human chorionic gonadotropin. Laboratory testing reveals a random glucose level of 160 mg/dL (reference range, <140) and an elevated free testosterone level. Serum levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone, follicle-stimulating hormone, prolactin, 17-hydroxyprogesterone, and lipids are normal. Cortisol levels in a late-night saliva sample are within the reference range.
You discuss smoking cessation with the patient and assess her readiness for change, as well as options for treating her menstrual irregularity, acne, and hirsutism. A follow-up appointment is scheduled in one month.
Which one of the following tests should be ordered next?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient meets the Rotterdam criteria for polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) given the presence of features of ovulatory dysfunction (chronically irregular menses) and hyperandrogenism (acne, hirsutism, and elevated free testosterone level). When considering PCOS, clinicians should conduct testing to rule out pregnancy and differential diagnoses of PCOS, such as thyroid disease, hyperprolactinemia, and nonclassic congenital adrenal hyperplasia.

Patients with PCOS are at increased risk for metabolic syndrome, a group of conditions including hypertension, abdominal obesity, dyslipidemia, and glucose intolerance. All patients with PCOS should be screened for metabolic syndrome with regular measurements of blood pressure, waist circumference, fasting lipid profiles, and tests for prediabetes or type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). Abnormal results suggesting metabolic syndrome in women include blood pressure ≥130/85 mm Hg, waist circumference ≥35 inches, HDL-cholesterol level ≤50 mg/dL, triglyceride level ≥150 mg/dL, fasting glucose level ≥110 mg/dL, and a 2-hour postprandial glucose level ≥140 mg/dL.

This patient's mildly elevated random (nonfasting) glucose level of 160 mg/dL is concerning but not diagnostic of prediabetes or T2DM. Although this patient’s BMI is currently in the healthy range (18.5–24.9), she has risk factors for glucose intolerance, including PCOS and a family history of T2DM. Because PCOS is associated with a 5- to 10-fold increased risk for prediabetes and T2DM, screening for these conditions is recommended upon diagnosis of PCOS and should be conducted regularly (typically every 1 to 3 years). The preferred screening approach in patients with PCOS is a 2-hour oral glucose tolerance testing (OGTT) with a 75-gram glucose load. A glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) test and fasting plasma glucose levels are more convenient than a formal 2-hour OGTT, but they are less sensitive. This is because in the early stages of glucose intolerance, the physiologic mechanisms that maintain euglycemia may be able to keep both the fasting blood glucose level and the average blood glucose level (which is assessed using HbA1c) normal. If a patient with PCOS is unable or unwilling to complete an OGTT, an HbA1c test or fasting plasma glucose level may be considered.

Key learning point: Patients with polycystic ovary syndrome should be screened for metabolic syndrome at diagnosis and regularly thereafter, using waist circumference, blood pressure, fasting lipid levels, and a 2-hour oral glucose tolerance test.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with PCOS are at increased risk for nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, but current guidelines do not recommend screening for this disorder in individuals without overweight.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient, with features of ovulatory dysfunction and hyperandrogenism, already meets the Rotterdam criteria for polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). While ultrasonography can confirm polycystic ovarian morphology, it is not routinely required for the diagnosis or initial workup of PCOS. Due to the increased risk of endometrial cancer associated with PCOS, transvaginal ultrasonography may be considered if an older woman with PCOS experiences symptoms such as intermenstrual or heavy menstrual bleeding.

D) INCORRECT:

Nonclassic congenital adrenal hyperplasia may manifest in adolescence or young adulthood with symptoms of hyperandrogenism. Although evaluation for nonclassic congenital adrenal hyperplasia includes an adrenocorticotropic hormone stimulation test, it is not indicated in this patient who has a normal 17-hydroxyprogesterone level.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with PCOS are at an increased risk for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and should be evaluated for OSA symptoms regardless of BMI. Polysomnography, however, is not routinely needed in the workup of PCOS. It is performed only to confirm an OSA diagnosis if the patient has OSA symptoms or tests positive on a standardized OSA screening questionnaire.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the office for the evaluation of infertility. She has been unable to conceive for the past 2 years. Menses occur at 45 to 80-day intervals. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 77 kg (170 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m2. Physical examination shows facial acne and pigmented hair on the upper lip. Serum studies show elevated levels of testosterone and an LH:FSH ratio of 4:1. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bromocriptine is used in individuals with anovulatory infertility due to hyperprolactinemia. Elevated serum prolactin levels inhibit GnRH secretion, resulting in low levels of FSH and LH (hypogonadotropic hypogonadism). Patients would present with anovulation, amenorrhea, galactorrhea, and possibly symptoms of a pituitary macroadenoma (headaches, bitemporal hemianopia). Bromocriptine is not used to treat infertility caused by PCOS.

B) INCORRECT:

Mifepristone is used in conjunction with a prostaglandin analog (e.g., misoprostol) for medical termination of pregnancy. It is not used to treat infertility in PCOS.

C) INCORRECT:

LH and human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) have a similar molecular structure and share the same receptors. Injectable hCG causes an LH surge that stimulates ovarian follicular maturation and ovulation and is therefore used to induce ovulation in patients with infertility. However, it is only a second-line treatment in PCOS because of its higher costs and an increased risk of multiple pregnancy.

D) CORRECT:

Letrozole inhibits the conversion of androgens to estrogens and lowers estrogen levels, which stimulates FSH secretion and induces ovulation. Treatment with letrozole leads to higher live birth rates than clomiphene citrate, making it the first-line treatment for individuals with PCOS who wish to conceive.

E) INCORRECT:

Clomiphene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator used for inducing ovulation in individuals with infertility due to PCOS. Clomiphene binds to the hypothalamic estrogen receptors, thereby blocking the negative feedback effect of circulating endogenous estradiol. This results in an increase in the pulsatile secretion of GnRH and subsequent increase in both FSH and LH, stimulating ovulation. Clomiphene induces ovulation in about 80% of patients with PCOS and leads to conception in approximately about 50%, but another drug is the first-line treatment for this condition.
questions.hint: This patient's oligomenorrhea, clinical and laboratory signs of hyperandrogenemia (facial acne, hirsutism, elevated serum testosterone), and LH:FSH ratio > 2:1 suggest that her infertility is due to polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the office for the evaluation of irregular menstrual bleeding. Menses have occurred at 45-to-90-day intervals since menarche at the age of 15 years. Her last menstrual period was 5 weeks ago. Over the past two years, she has been unable to become pregnant despite having unprotected sexual intercourse with her husband on a regular basis. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 90 kg (198 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows oily skin and severe facial acne. There is abnormal pigmented hair on the upper lip and around both nipples. The patient wishes to have children. In addition to recommending lifestyle modifications, which of the following is most appropriate to treat this patient's infertility?

choices.text: In vitro fertilization with patient's oocyte

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In vitro fertilization should be suggested to this patient if first-line and second-line treatment options, e.g., weight loss and ovulation induction with medical therapy, do not provide the desired results. This patient has not yet received any treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Progesterone is a steroid hormone that prepares the uterus for implantation and maintains pregnancy. It can be given in cases of recurrent pregnancy loss due to a luteal phase defect. This patient presents with PCOS and has an anovulatory cycle. Therefore, the next steps should be aimed at ovulation induction.

C) INCORRECT:

Bromocriptine is used in women with anovulatory infertility due to hyperprolactinemia, which can cause oligomenorrhea and infertility but would not explain this patient's hirsutism. Moreover, she lacks other common symptoms of hyperprolactinemia, such as galactorrhea and loss of libido.

D) CORRECT:

Letrozole for ovulation induction is a first-line pharmacotherapy for patients with PCOS who wish to conceive. By inhibiting aromatase, letrozole reduces estrogen production, stimulating FSH secretion and thus inducing ovulation. Letrozole is associated with higher live birth rates than clomiphene citrate, another first-line treatment option for ovulation induction in patients with PCOS. Although letrozole is not FDA-approved for this indication, multiple studies have demonstrated its effectiveness and safety, and it is widely used off-label.

Obesity can contribute to increased estrogen secretion and hyperinsulinemia, which are the underlying causes of LH and FSH imbalances that lead to impaired follicle maturation and consequent oligoovulation or anovulation. Therefore, patients with obesity should be advised on lifestyle modifications aimed at weight loss. In patients with insulin resistance, metformin may be added to the treatment regimen.

E) INCORRECT:

Gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists (e.g., leuprolide) lead to a downregulation of the pituitary gland's release of gonadotropins to prevent premature ovulation. Leuprolide can be used prior to an in vitro fertilization (IVF) cycle with controlled ovarian stimulation. In patients with PCOS, IVF in addition to leuprolide therapy should be considered if first-line and second-line treatment options, such as weight loss and ovulation induction with medical therapy, do not provide the desired results. However, this woman has not yet been treated with first-line or second-line treatment options.
questions.hint: This patient presents with oligomenorrhea, symptoms of hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne vulgaris), and infertility. Together with obesity, these features suggest polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with irregular menstrual bleeding. Menses have occurred at 60- to 90-day intervals since menarche at the age of 12 years. Her last menstrual period was 4 weeks ago. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms consistently. She reports that she currently has no desire to have children. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 85 kg (187 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Examination shows scattered pustules on the forehead and oily skin. There is coarse hair on the chin and upper lip. Fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 190 mg/dL. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Letrozole is a first-line treatment for women with PCOS who wish to conceive. This medication decreases estrogen levels, which are increased in patients with PCOS due to increased aromatization of androgens. This effect can result in the regulation of folliculogenesis and subsequent ovulation. However, since this young patient currently has no desire to conceive, increasing her fertility is not warranted at this point.

B) INCORRECT:

Gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists, such as leuprolide, can suppress or stimulate the release of luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone, depending on the manner of administration (i.e., continuous or pulsatile). While the pulsatile use of leuprolide is indicated for certain causes of infertility, it is not indicated in PCOS. Continuous administration of GnRH agonists may be used to suppress androgen production in patients with PCOS. However, additional therapy with estrogen and progestin is necessary to prevent symptoms of premature ovarian failure, making these drugs a costly and complicated treatment option that is not routinely indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Clomiphene citrate is a first-line pharmacotherapy in patients with PCOS who have a desire to conceive. This medication increases the secretion of luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone, thereby stimulating ovulation. Although infertility due to oligoovulation or anovulation is one of the main concerns in patients with PCOS, this young woman currently has no desire to get pregnant, which is why pharmacotherapy should focus on relieving symptoms instead.

D) INCORRECT:

Metformin is used to treat type 2 diabetes mellitus and is initiated at the time of diagnosis in addition to lifestyle modifications for weight loss. In patients without symptoms of hyperglycemia (e.g., polyuria), diagnosis of type 2 diabetes mellitus requires ≥ 2 abnormal test results for hyperglycemia. A single random elevated plasma glucose measurement of 190 mg/dL is insufficient for the diagnosis in asymptomatic patients and further workup is required before prescribing metformin for glycemic control.

In addition, metformin is used in patients with PCOS and decreased insulin sensitivity to improve menstrual irregularities, metabolic outcomes, and weight loss. However, metformin monotherapy is only used in PCOS as a second-line treatment for menstrual irregularities in patients with contraindications for the first-line options, which this patient does not have. Finally, metformin may be used as an adjunct to first-line pharmacotherapy, which this patient has not yet received, to address metabolic comorbidities.

E) CORRECT:

A combination oral contraceptive pill (COCP) containing ethinylestradiol and progestin is the first-line pharmacotherapy for patients with PCOS who currently do not wish to conceive. COCPs help regulate the menstrual cycle and, because of antiandrogenic effects, relieve symptoms of hyperandrogenism. In addition, progestin decreases the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and cancer, which are possible complications of PCOS (due to the increased levels of estrogen from aromatization of androgens). Besides pharmacotherapy, weight loss is the mainstay of treatment because obesity and the associated insulin resistance play an important role in the pathophysiology of PCOS.

Metformin may be used as an add-on to COCPs and lifestyle modifications to address metabolic comorbidities (e.g., impaired insulin sensitivity). Monotherapy with metformin may be considered as a second-line treatment for menstrual irregularity in patients unable to take or tolerate COCPs.
questions.hint: This patient presents with oligomenorrhea and symptoms of hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne vulgaris). These features together with obesity and decreased insulin sensitivity (as evidenced by elevated blood glucose levels) suggest polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman presents for a health maintenance examination at her university health center. Her periods have never been regular, occurring every 40 to 90 days. Her blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg, and her BMI is 24 kg/m2. On examination, comedones are noted on her forehead, nose, and cheeks (figure), along with a moderate amount of dark hair above her upper lip, chin, and lower abdomen. A urine sample is negative for human chorionic gonadotropin. Laboratory testing reveals an elevated random glucose level and an elevated free testosterone level. Levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone, follicle-stimulating hormone, prolactin, 17-hydroxyprogesterone, and lipids are all normal. Which one of the following tests should be ordered next?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patients with PCOS are at increased risk for metabolic syndrome, a group of conditions that increase the risk for type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and cardiovascular disease. These conditions include hypertension, abdominal obesity, dyslipidemia, and impaired fasting glucose. All patients with PCOS should be screened for metabolic syndrome with regular measurements of blood pressure and waist circumference, fasting lipid profiles, and 2-hour oral glucose tolerance testing (OGTT). Although this patient’s BMI is currently in the healthy range (18.5–24.9), PCOS increases the risk of prediabetes and T2DM 5- to 10-fold. Therefore, it is important to assess for early T2DM.

When considering PCOS, clinicians should conduct testing to rule out pregnancy and differential diagnoses of PCOS, such as thyroid disease, hyperprolactinemia, and nonclassic congenital adrenal hyperplasia.

Key Learning Point: Patients with polycystic ovary syndrome should be screened for metabolic syndrome at diagnosis and again every 3 to 5 years, with measurement of blood pressure, fasting lipid levels, and a 2-hour oral glucose tolerance test.

B) INCORRECT:

Transvaginal ultrasound is not necessary or appropriate for this patient, who already meets the criteria for PCOS. Ultrasonography may be used to rule out rare ovarian or adrenal tumors in individuals with low concern for PCOS. Another test should be ordered in a patient with suspected PCOS and an elevated random glucose level.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with PCOS are at increased risk for nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, but current guidelines do not recommend screening for this disorder in individuals without overweight.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with PCOS are at increased risk for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). Because overweight is also a risk factor for OSA, patients with PCOS and overweight should be screened for symptoms of the condition. If symptoms are present, polysomnography should be ordered. This patient does not have overweight or symptoms of OSA.

E) INCORRECT:

Nonclassic congenital adrenal hyperplasia may manifest in adolescence or young adulthood with symptoms of hyperandrogenism, such as acne, hirsutism, and oligomenorrhea. Although evaluation for nonclassic congenital adrenal hyperplasia includes an adrenocorticotropic hormone stimulation test, it is not indicated in this patient who has a normal 17-hydroxyprogesterone level.
questions.hint: This patient's chronically irregular menses and features of hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne, elevated testosterone) indicate polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

questions.text: A 19-year-old nulligravid woman presents with irregular heavy menstrual bleeding since menarche at the age of 16 years. Menses occur at irregular 15- to 45-day intervals and last 7 to 10 days. She has also noted increased hair growth on her face. She has acne vulgaris treated with topical retinoids. Her 70-year-old grandmother has breast cancer. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (181 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Pelvic examination shows copious cervical mucus and slightly enlarged irregular ovaries. If left untreated, this patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Choriocarcinoma is a rare type of gestational trophoblastic disease that only develops after fertilization and implantation of the oocyte. This patient with PCOS actually has a lower risk of developing choriocarcinoma, as chronic anovulation is a hallmark of PCOS, which renders the patient infertile.

B) CORRECT:

In the normal menstrual cycle, estrogen-driven endometrial proliferation (proliferative phase) is opposed by a progesterone-driven secretory phase. Chronic anovulation in PCOS results in prolonged estrogen exposure of the endometrium unopposed by progesterone, which increases the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and endometrial carcinoma. Endometrial carcinoma is the most common cancer of the female genital tract in the US. This malignancy primarily affects postmenopausal women (peak incidence at 65–74 years) and abnormal uterine bleeding is the main symptom, with later stages manifesting with pelvic pain, a palpable abdominal mass, and weight loss.

C) INCORRECT:

Cervical cancer is strongly associated with human papillomavirus infection and the incidence and mortality of cervical cancer in developed countries have significantly declined since the introduction of routine Pap smear screening. There is insufficient evidence to confirm that PCOS is associated with an increased risk of cervical cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Osteoporosis most commonly affects postmenopausal women due to a decline in the protective effect of estrogen on bone after menopause. PCOS may be associated with a decrease in bone density and an increased risk of osteoporosis, but another complication is more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Although PCOS is associated with prolonged estrogen exposure (due to anovulatory cycles and nulliparity), which is a known risk factor for the development of breast cancer, studies were unable to confirm an increased risk of breast cancer in patients with PCOS.
questions.hint: Hyperandrogenic anovulation (as evidenced by delayed menarche, irregular menses, hirsutism, and acne) and obesity are characteristic of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the office because menarche has not yet occurred. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is 162 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 80 kg (176 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Breast and pubic hair development is Tanner stage 4. She also has oily skin, acne, and hyperpigmentation of the intertriginous areas of her neck and axillae. The remainder of the examination, including pelvic examination, shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) can cause primary amenorrhea, as it causes development failure of the female internal reproductive structures in utero. However, patients with AIS will have scant pubic hair, and pelvic examination will show a vagina that ends in a blind pouch without a cervix. This patient's Tanner stage 4 pubic hair and normal pelvic examination are not consistent with AIS.

B) INCORRECT:

XO chromosomal abnormality is the cause of Turner syndrome, which is one of the most common etiologies of primary amenorrhea (due to gonadal dysgenesis). However, this patient does not have any of the dysmorphic features of Turner syndrome (e.g., short stature, webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, low hairline) that would suggest this diagnosis. Furthermore, Turner syndrome is not associated with hyperandrogenism or insulin resistance.

C) INCORRECT:

Müllerian agenesis can manifest with primary amenorrhea (due to lack of uterine development) with normal secondary sexual characteristics (due to functional ovaries). However, pelvic examination would show vaginal atresia. Furthermore, this patient's hyperandrogenism and insulin resistance suggests a hormonal imbalance as the cause of her amenorrhea rather than a congenital malformation.

D) CORRECT:

Patients with PCOS have hyperinsulinemia, which is thought to cause increased androgen production by theca cells and increased pituitary LH secretion. Hyperandrogenism and disrupted LH/FSH balance, resulting in elevated LH:FSH ratio, impair follicle maturation, preventing ovulation and progesterone release from the corpus luteum. As a result, there is only estrogen-driven endometrial proliferation (proliferative phase) without a progesterone-driven secretory phase. Without regular shedding of the endometrium, the endometrium can become thick and unstable, resulting in irregular, heavy uterine bleeding, and/or primary amenorrhea. Furthermore, unopposed estrogen-driven endometrial proliferation increases the risk for endometrial hyperplasia and type 1 endometrial cancer.

First-line treatment includes lifestyle modifications to treat obesity if applicable (goal BMI < 25 kg/m2) and, for patients who do not wish to conceive, oral contraceptives to regulate menstrual periods, or, in patients who do wish to conceive, pharmacological induction of ovulation (e.g., with letrozole or clomiphene).

Key learning point: An elevated LH:FSH ratio is characteristic of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), leading to anovulation, hyperandrogenism, and menstrual irregularities such as amenorrhea.
Image Description:

In polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), peripheral insulin resistance (e.g., due to obesity) causes hyperinsulinemia. Hyperinsulinemia stimulates androgen production in cells of the ovarian theca interna. Levels of free androgens are further increased by reduced sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) production in the liver. Hyperandrogenemia stimulates LH release from the anterior pituitary gland, resulting in a disruption of LH/FSH balance and, consequently, impaired follicle maturation. LH/FSH balance is further impaired by increased GnRH pulsatility in the hypothalamus and the conversion of androgens to estrogen in adipose tissue.

E) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum cortisol levels would suggest Cushing syndrome, which can cause primary amenorrhea, hyperandrogenism, and insulin resistance. However, this patient does not have any other features of Cushing syndrome (e.g., striae, buffalo hump, central obesity with wasting of extremities, hypertension). Moreover, Cushing syndrome is a rarer cause of amenorrhea, hyperandrogenism, and insulin resistance than PCOS, and cortisol levels in PCOS are usually normal.
questions.hint: Primary amenorrhea in an adolescent with features of hyperandrogenism (acne, oily skin), features of insulin resistance (obesity, benign acanthosis nigricans), and normal pubertal changes of the breast and pubic hair is highly suggestive of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with persistent acne and excessive facial and chest hair. She initially presented 7 months ago for evaluation of irregular menses that occurred at 28 to 36-day intervals for 8 days with moderate flow and was started on a combined oral contraceptive. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. She is 157 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows excessive hair growth on the upper lip, in the periareolar area, and along the linea alba. Dermatological examination shows comedones and inflammatory papules on the face and back. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator most commonly used for the treatment of breast cancer. It is not indicated for this patient with PCOS and hirsutism.

B) CORRECT:

Spironolactone is an aldosterone receptor antagonist with antiandrogenic properties that is considered one of the most effective second-line treatment options for patients with hirsutism. Spironolactone can be used in patients with hirsutism that have shown minimal to no response after treatment with COCs for at least 6 months or in those who cannot take COCs.

In patients with renal dysfunction, spironolactone should be avoided because it can lead to metabolic and electrolyte imbalances, such as hyperkalemia, hyponatremia, and metabolic acidosis. If used as monotherapy (e.g., in women with contraindications to COCs), spironolactone should be combined with other contraceptive methods since it carries a risk of undervirilization in male fetuses.

C) INCORRECT:

Flutamide is an androgen receptor blocker that can be used to treat hirsutism in patients who showed no improvement with COCs. However, flutamide is generally avoided because of potentially severe adverse effects (e.g., fatal hepatotoxicity). Other (safer) antiandrogenic agents should be considered in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Photoepilation therapy is a direct and permanent hair removal method that may be used for patients with hirsutism. However, photoepilation does not reduce the increased androgen levels in patients with PCOS, which means hair regrowth may occur later on. Finally, other clinical features of hyperandrogenism, e.g., acne, or androgenic alopecia, would still persist in these patients.

E) INCORRECT:

Danazol is a synthetic androgen with antigonadotropic (decreased luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone) and antiestrogenic effects most commonly used for the treatment of endometriosis or fibrocystic breast disease. In PCOS, however, androgen levels are typically increased, which is why antiandrogens, not androgen agonists, should be used to improve this patient's hirsutism.
questions.hint: Clinical hyperandrogenism and menstrual irregularities are diagnostic of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Since this patient's hyperandrogenic features (hirsutism, acne) have not improved after 6 months of treatment with combined oral contraceptives (COCs), an antiandrogenic agent should be considered to relieve her symptoms.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman comes to the office because of irregular menstrual bleeding. Menarche occurred at the age of 12 years and menses have occurred at 45 to 90-day intervals. Her last menstrual period was 8 weeks ago. She is not sexually active. Serum studies show:


Fasting glucose
178 mg/dL


Fasting insulin
29 mcIU/mL (N = 2.6–24.9)


Luteinizing hormone
160 mIU/mL


Total testosterone

3.2 ng/dL (N = 0.06–1.06)


Serum electrolytes are within the reference range. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Intrasellar mass on cranial contrast MRI

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum beta-HCG levels would indicate pregnancy, which should be ruled out in any woman with secondary amenorrhea. However, this woman is not sexually active, which makes pregnancy highly unlikely. Furthermore, insulin resistance and an elevation in testosterone and LH would not be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

An adrenal tumor in the setting of oligomenorrhea would be suggestive of adrenal adenoma causing primary hypercortisolism (ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome). The high levels of cortisol cause negative feedback on the pituitary and suppress ACTH release, leading to insulin resistance and irregular menstrual cycles, which are present in this patient. However, this patient's elevated LH and duration of symptoms (irregular menses since age 12) makes an adrenal tumor unlikely.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's features (e.g., oligomenorrhea, insulin resistance, elevated testosterone levels) are highly suggestive of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). PCOS is an endocrinological disorder characterized by peripheral insulin resistance with subsequent hyperinsulinemia and excess androgen production from the theca interna cells. PCOS manifests with decreased follicular maturation, which leads to unruptured follicles (e.g., cysts) and anovulation. Transvaginal ultrasound will typically show bilateral, anechoic cysts and ovarian enlargement.

D) INCORRECT:

An intrasellar mass on cranial contrast MRI in the setting of oligomenorrhea would indicate a prolactinoma, a prolactin-producing tumor of the anterior pituitary gland that is usually benign. However, laboratory tests would not show elevated LH and testosterone or insulin resistance. The duration of this patient's symptoms (irregular menses since age 12), moreover, makes a prolactinoma unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum TSH is seen in hypothyroidism. Although hypothyroidism could cause oligomenorrhea, it would not explain the elevated testosterone or signs of insulin resistance seen here. Furthermore, this patient lacks other typical symptoms such as fatigue, bradycardia, cold intolerance, constipation, and weight gain.
questions.hint: This woman with oligomenorrhea has elevated testosterone and LH levels, as well as evidence of insulin resistance (increased fasting glucose and fasting insulin). Hirsutism and acne would be expected on examination.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the office for an annual health maintenance examination. She feels well. She is 155 cm (5 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (174 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Examination shows a skin rash over both axillae. A photograph of her left axilla is shown. This patient's skin finding is most likely associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Niacin deficiency causes pellagra, which manifests with a symmetrical, thickened, and hyperpigmented rash. However, the rash typically occurs in areas of the skin exposed to the sunlight (e.g., face, neck, hands) rather than in the axillae, as seen here. Moreover, further symptoms of pellagra, such as vomiting, diarrhea, atrophic glossitis, and neurological symptoms are absent in this patient. Niacin deficiency is not associated with acanthosis nigricans.

Pellagra and acanthosis nigricans can both manifest with a collar around the neck; also referred to as Casal necklace in the case of pellagra. However, the skin in niacin deficiency looks sun-burnt rather than velvety as seen here.
Image Description:

There are symmetrical, hyperpigmented, hyperkeratotic plaques on sun-exposed areas of the chest (Casal necklace), shoulders, face, hands, and arms.

This is the typical dermatological manifestation of pellagra. Dermatitis is one of the “4 D's of pellagra” alongside diarrhea, dementia, and death.

B) INCORRECT:

Gastrointestinal malignancies can manifest with acanthosis nigricans. However, if this skin finding occurs in association with a malignancy, such as paraneoplastic syndrome, it is characterized by rapid onset, a verrucous or papulous surface, and involvement of atypical sites (e.g., palms, soles, or mucous membranes), which is not the case in this patient. Moreover, malignant acanthosis nigricans is associated with gastric adenocarcinoma, not gastric malignant lymphoma. Lastly, gastric cancer is rare in young adults and this woman has no signs of gastrointestinal malignancy such as weight loss, anemia, abdominal discomfort, or melena.
Image Description:

Hyperpigmentation, hyperkeratosis, and numerous skin tags (papillomatosis) are visible on the right axilla.

These findings are consistent with acanthosis nigricans.

C) INCORRECT:

Primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison disease) presents with hyperpigmented skin lesions caused by the stimulant effects of excess ACTH on the melanocytes which produce melanin (bronze disease). Unlike the skin finding in this patient, the hyperpigmentation in Addison disease is typically generalized and often involves the palm creases or oral mucosa. Instead of obesity, patients with Addison disease present with weight loss and anorexia due to hypocortisolism. Lastly, the absence of other symptoms such as hypotension and intestinal complaints (nausea, vomiting, and/or diarrhea), make Addison disease unlikely.

D) CORRECT:

Acanthosis nigricans is commonly seen in disorders characterized by insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia (e.g., polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), obesity, diabetes mellitus, acromegaly). Elevated levels of insulin stimulate keratinocyte and dermal fibroblast proliferation via interaction with insulin-like growth factor 1, resulting in epidermal hyperplasia and plaque-like lesions. In addition, insulin resistance in PCOS is responsible for hyperandrogenism (leading to acne, hirsutism) and anovulation (causing amenorrhea and impaired fertility).

Similar skin changes can be caused by obesity alone, in which case the disorder is referred to as pseudoacanthosis nigricans.

E) INCORRECT:

Pregnancy is associated with hyperpigmentation due to increased melanocyte-stimulating hormone produced by the placenta. Although the axillae may be affected, hyperpigmentation of the linea alba, the nipples, areola, and the face (i.e., melasma) are far more common. Moreover, the hyperpigmented macules and patches often seen during pregnancy are not thickened and velvety as seen here. Pregnancy is not associated with acanthosis nigricans.
Image Description:

Hyperpigmented brown, irregularly shaped patches are visible on both sides of the upper and lower cutaneous lip.

These features are characteristic of melasma, which typically has a centrofacial distribution.
questions.hint: The picture shows acanthosis nigricans, a skin condition that manifests with thickened, velvety, hyperpigmented plaques and most frequently involves intertriginous sites such as the axillae or the neck.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman presents to the clinic with difficulty conceiving for the past 15 months. Her menstrual cycles have been irregular for several years, sometimes occurring every 40 to 50 days or skipping entire months. She has no history of major illnesses or surgeries. Her husband’s semen analysis is within normal limits. She is slightly overweight with a BMI of 28 kg/m². Physical examination reveals mild hirsutism on her chin and lower abdomen, and she reports occasional acne flare-ups. Serum TSH and prolactin levels are normal (see report).
Pelvic ultrasound: Bilaterally enlarged ovaries with multiple small follicular structures
Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Premature ovarian insufficiency involves diminished ovarian reserve and hypoestrogenism, often with atrophic ovaries on ultrasound. The patient's hirsutism and acne suggest androgen excess, not typical of this condition. The menstrual pattern and ovarian morphology indicate a different endocrine dysfunction.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperprolactinemia can cause menstrual irregularities and infertility, but normal serum prolactin levels rule it out. Symptoms like galactorrhea or pituitary-related signs are absent. The ultrasound findings of enlarged ovaries with multiple follicles are not typical of hyperprolactinemia.

C) CORRECT:

Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) manifests with chronic anovulation, leading to infertility. The patient's irregular menstrual cycles indicate oligo-ovulation, a hallmark of PCOS, caused by dysregulated gonadotropin secretion and an elevated luteinizing hormone (LH) to follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) ratio. Clinical hyperandrogenism is evident through hirsutism and acne, reflecting hormonal imbalances typical of PCOS. The pelvic ultrasound shows bilaterally enlarged ovaries with multiple peripheral follicles, meeting imaging criteria for PCOS. These clinical and imaging findings, combined with anovulatory infertility, support the diagnosis of PCOS.

Key learning point: Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is a common cause of infertility due to ovulatory dysfunction, characterized by irregular menstrual cycles and ultrasound findings of multiple small cysts in the ovaries.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism can cause menstrual irregularities and subfertility, but normal TSH levels exclude thyroid dysfunction. Systemic symptoms like cold intolerance and fatigue are absent. The reproductive and metabolic profile aligns with another condition, not hypothyroidism.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman presents with an 8-month history of infrequent menstruation and unwanted facial hair that has gradually worsened. She is overweight with a BMI of 29 and has notable acne. Pelvic examination is normal. Serum testosterone is mildly elevated, while thyroid function tests and serum prolactin levels are normal (see report).
Ultrasound: Multiple small cysts on both ovaries
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) manifests with hyperandrogenism, chronic anovulation, and polycystic ovaries. The patient's irregular menses, hirsutism, and acne suggest androgen excess. Ultrasound findings of multiple ovarian cysts and mildly elevated serum testosterone align with PCOS diagnostic criteria, such as the Rotterdam criteria. Normal thyroid and prolactin levels exclude other endocrine disorders. The combination of hormonal imbalances and ovarian morphology is characteristic of PCOS.

Key learning point: Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS) is characterized by oligomenorrhea, hirsutism, obesity, and the presence of multiple small ovarian follicles on ultrasound.

B) INCORRECT:

Cushing syndrome may cause menstrual irregularities and hirsutism due to excess cortisol. However, the absence of classic features like a 'moon' face or purple striae, and the presence of multiple ovarian cysts, suggest an ovarian dysfunction rather than cortisol excess. The mildly elevated serum testosterone supports an ovarian source of androgen overproduction.

C) INCORRECT:

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia can present with hirsutism and irregular menstruation. However, it typically involves elevated adrenal androgen precursors, cortisol deficiency, or electrolyte imbalances, which are absent here. The ultrasound finding of multiple ovarian cysts is not typical of adrenal hyperplasia, indicating an ovarian rather than adrenal origin of hyperandrogenism.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism can cause menstrual irregularities and weight gain, but normal thyroid function tests exclude this diagnosis. Additionally, hypothyroidism does not typically present with hyperandrogenism signs like hirsutism and acne. The ultrasound finding of multiple ovarian cysts is not associated with hypothyroidism.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents with a 14-month history of difficulty conceiving. Her menstrual cycles vary between 35 and 60 days, and she notes excessive hair growth on her face and chin. She experiences occasional acne but no breast discharge. She denies significant stress, weight changes, or hot flashes. Her BMI is 30. Physical examination reveals no thyroid enlargement, and pelvic examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) manifests with irregular menstrual cycles, such as those ranging from 35 to 60 days, indicating chronic anovulation. Hyperandrogenic features, including hirsutism and acne, result from disrupted ovarian steroidogenesis. Obesity exacerbates insulin resistance, further increasing androgen levels. This combination of endocrine and metabolic disturbances impairs oocyte development and release, leading to infertility. The diagnostic framework for PCOS centers on anovulation and clinical signs of androgen excess.

Key learning point: Irregular menstrual cycles in women are often indicative of ovulatory dysfunction, which is a common cause of infertility.

B) INCORRECT:

Primary ovarian insufficiency typically presents with estrogen deficiency symptoms like hot flashes and amenorrhea, contrasting with this patient's presentation. The condition is characterized by elevated gonadotropins and low estrogen, not the androgen excess seen here. The absence of menopausal symptoms and the presence of hyperandrogenic features and obesity do not align with primary ovarian insufficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism can cause menstrual irregularities and infertility but does not typically present with androgen excess features like hirsutism and acne. Additional systemic findings, such as fatigue or cold intolerance, are expected in hypothyroidism but are not mentioned. A normal thyroid examination further argues against this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperprolactinemia is associated with menstrual irregularities and infertility but often presents with galactorrhea, which is absent here. Hirsutism and acne suggest hyperandrogenism, not typical of hyperprolactinemia. Menstrual disturbances in hyperprolactinemia are due to reduced gonadotropin-releasing hormone secretion, not androgen excess.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of infrequent menstrual cycles, difficulty losing weight, and new onset facial hair growth. She expresses concern about her inability to conceive for the past year. Her body mass index is 32 kg/m². Physical examination reveals coarse hair on her upper lip and chin, and patches of dark, velvety discoloration in her neck folds. Laboratory studies show normal thyroid function.
Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nonclassic congenital adrenal hyperplasia (NCAH) involves partial enzyme deficiency, often 21-hydroxylase, leading to hyperandrogenism with menstrual irregularities and hirsutism. However, obesity and acanthosis nigricans indicate insulin resistance, not an adrenal defect. NCAH typically shows elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels, absent here.

B) INCORRECT:

Idiopathic hirsutism presents with excessive hair growth in androgen-dependent areas but normal menstrual cycles and no systemic abnormalities. The patient's infrequent menstrual cycles, obesity, and acanthosis nigricans suggest an underlying endocrine disturbance beyond idiopathic hirsutism.

C) CORRECT:

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) manifests with menstrual irregularities due to chronic anovulation and clinical hyperandrogenism. The patient's infrequent menstrual cycles and facial hair growth indicate disrupted ovulatory cycles and androgen excess. Obesity exacerbates insulin resistance, contributing to acanthosis nigricans and increased ovarian androgen production. This androgen excess disrupts gonadotropin balance, leading to further menstrual dysfunction and infertility. These clinical findings align with the pathophysiology of PCOS.

Key learning point: Acanthosis nigricans, irregular menses, infertility, and hirsutism in a young woman are suggestive of Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome, which is associated with insulin resistance and hyperandrogenism.

D) INCORRECT:

Cushing syndrome can cause weight gain and hirsutism due to excess cortisol. However, features like moon facies, buffalo hump, and purple striae are absent. Acanthosis nigricans suggests insulin resistance, not typical of Cushing syndrome without other cortisol excess signs.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old woman presents with irregular monthly cycles for the last 14 months, reporting only scant spotting at inconsistent intervals. She has noticed coarse hair growth on her chin and chest, along with a recent 15-pound weight gain. She denies significant stress or changes in daily routine. Examination reveals thickened, velvety skin at the neck folds. There are no signs of thyroid enlargement.

Blood pressure
148/92 mm Hg

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism can cause menstrual irregularities and weight gain but typically presents with fatigue, cold intolerance, constipation, and sometimes a goiter, none of which are noted here. Hirsutism and acanthosis nigricans suggest androgen excess and insulin resistance, not thyroid hormone deficiency. The high blood pressure and insulin resistance markers are not typical of hypothyroidism.

B) INCORRECT:

Cushing syndrome can cause weight gain, menstrual irregularities, hirsutism, and hypertension. However, it typically presents with a moon face, buffalo hump, purple striae, and proximal muscle weakness, which are absent here. Acanthosis nigricans suggests insulin resistance, not hypercortisolism. The weight gain pattern does not match the central adiposity seen in Cushing syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) involves enzyme deficiencies causing adrenal hyperandrogenism. Classic forms present in infancy with ambiguous genitalia or salt-wasting. Non-classical CAH can cause menstrual irregularity and hirsutism but lacks the insulin resistance and hypertension seen here. The absence of early-life manifestations and adrenal insufficiency signs makes CAH unlikely.

D) CORRECT:

The patient presents with irregular menstrual cycles, hirsutism, weight gain, and acanthosis nigricans, which are indicative of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). PCOS is characterized by chronic anovulation, leading to menstrual irregularities. Hirsutism results from androgen excess, often due to ovarian overproduction. The weight gain and acanthosis nigricans suggest insulin resistance, a common metabolic disturbance in PCOS. These features, along with the patient's age, align with the diagnosis of PCOS, which involves disrupted gonadotropin secretion, hyperandrogenism, and metabolic dysfunction.

Key learning point: Stein-Leventhal syndrome, also known as polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), is characterized by multiple ovarian cysts, excessive androgen production, anovulation, insulin resistance, and symptoms such as hirsutism and hypertension.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old woman presents with a 9-month history of menstrual irregularities, typically experiencing a period every two to three months, and increasingly coarse hair growth on her upper lip and chin over the last year. Her BMI is 30 kg/m². Physical examination reveals mild acne on her face and dark, thick hair over her lower abdomen. Laboratory tests show slightly elevated total testosterone, an LH:FSH ratio of approximately 3:1, and normal TSH and prolactin levels (see report).
Pelvic ultrasound: Both ovaries are enlarged with multiple small follicles arranged peripherally
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nonclassic congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) can present with hyperandrogenic symptoms, but the elevated LH:FSH ratio and ultrasound findings suggest an ovarian source of androgen excess. Nonclassic CAH typically shows elevated adrenal hormones, such as 17-hydroxyprogesterone, which is not reported here. Obesity in this patient aligns more with ovarian dysfunction than adrenal hyperplasia.

B) INCORRECT:

Cushing syndrome can cause obesity, menstrual irregularities, and hirsutism, but the ultrasound findings of enlarged ovaries with multiple small follicles are not typical of cortisol excess. The hormonal profile, including the elevated LH:FSH ratio and modest testosterone increase, suggests an ovarian source of androgen excess rather than a glucocorticoid imbalance. Classic Cushing features like moon facies and striae are absent.

C) CORRECT:

The patient presents with features consistent with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), including irregular menstrual cycles indicative of chronic anovulation. Hyperandrogenism is evident through hirsutism and mild acne, supported by slightly elevated testosterone levels. The elevated LH:FSH ratio of approximately 3:1 reflects neuroendocrine disruption in PCOS, where increased luteinizing hormone (LH) stimulates ovarian theca cells to produce androgens. The ultrasound shows bilaterally enlarged ovaries with multiple small peripheral follicles, described as a 'string of pearls.' Obesity, common in PCOS, is associated with insulin resistance, exacerbating ovarian androgen production.

Key learning point: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) is characterized by hyperandrogenism, ovulatory dysfunction, and polycystic ovaries, often presenting with irregular menstrual periods, obesity, and elevated LH to FSH ratio.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism can cause menstrual irregularities and weight gain but is not typically associated with hyperandrogenic features like hirsutism and acne. The normal thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level contradicts hypothyroidism, which usually presents with elevated TSH. Additionally, hypothyroidism often includes symptoms like cold intolerance and fatigue, which are absent here.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman with a 4-year history of irregular menstrual cycles and known PCOS presents to the Outpatient Clinic. She discontinued cyclic progesterone three months ago. She reports increased weight gain and intermittent spotting for two weeks. Physical examination is normal (see report).
Transvaginal ultrasound: Mildly thickened endometrial stripe
Which intervention most effectively reduces her long-term risk of endometrial cancer?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Laparoscopic ovarian drilling induces ovulation in PCOS, primarily for infertility treatment. It does not ensure regular progesterone production to oppose estrogen's effects on the endometrium, which is necessary to reduce the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

Periodic transvaginal ultrasound monitoring evaluates structural changes in the endometrium but does not address the hormonal imbalance in PCOS. It cannot mitigate the risk of endometrial hyperplasia caused by unopposed estrogen exposure due to chronic anovulation.

C) CORRECT:

Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) often leads to chronic anovulation, resulting in prolonged unopposed estrogen exposure to the endometrium. This increases the risk of endometrial hyperplasia, a precursor to endometrial cancer. Cyclic progesterone supplementation induces secretory changes in the endometrium, followed by withdrawal bleeding, reducing the duration of unopposed estrogen exposure. This intervention decreases the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and carcinoma by ensuring regular endometrial shedding.

Key learning point: In women with PCOS, discontinuation of cyclic progesterone can lead to increased risk of endometrial carcinoma due to unopposed estrogen exposure.

D) INCORRECT:

Metformin improves insulin sensitivity and may aid in weight management and menstrual regularity in PCOS. However, it does not directly counteract the endometrial effects of unopposed estrogen exposure, which is crucial for reducing the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and cancer.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman with obesity, irregular menstruation, and increased facial hair for six months presents for evaluation. Examination reveals coarse hair on her chin and upper lip. What is the best initial biochemical test?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An elevated luteinizing hormone (LH) to follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) ratio is associated with PCOS due to altered gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) pulsatility. However, this ratio is not consistently elevated in all patients and is subject to variability. Serum androgen levels provide a more direct assessment of hyperandrogenemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Serum androstenedione, an androgen produced by the ovaries and adrenal glands, can be elevated in hyperandrogenic states like PCOS. However, its levels are less specific and more variable than testosterone, making it less suitable for initial screening. It is more useful for further clarification of the androgen profile in complex cases.

C) INCORRECT:

Hyperprolactinemia can cause menstrual irregularities but typically presents with galactorrhea or neurologic symptoms. The patient's symptoms of obesity, irregular menses, and hirsutism suggest an androgen excess state, such as PCOS, rather than a prolactin abnormality.

D) CORRECT:

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) is characterized by androgen excess, which manifests as hirsutism and irregular menstruation. Serum total testosterone is the most commonly used initial biochemical test to evaluate hyperandrogenism in PCOS. It detects modest elevations in testosterone levels, providing direct evidence of excess androgen production. This test is integral to the hormonal workup when PCOS is suspected, as it correlates with clinical findings and helps confirm the diagnosis.

Key learning point: Testosterone measurement is the best biochemical test for evaluating hirsutism, particularly in the context of PCOS, as it directly assesses hyperandrogenism.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman presents with progressively irregular menstrual cycles and coarse hair growth on her upper lip and chin over the last year. Her BMI is 30 kg/m2. She is not currently interested in pregnancy but is worried about her irregular periods and hirsutism (see lab results and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Thyroid-stimulating hormone
2.5 mIU/L
0.4 - 5.0 mIU/L


Testosterone
3.0 nmol/L
0.7 - 2.8 nmol/L


Human chorionic gonadotropin
0.3 mIU/mL
< 5 mIU/mL



Pelvic ultrasound: Bilaterally enlarged ovaries with multiple peripheral follicles
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Spironolactone is an antiandrogen that alleviates hirsutism by blocking androgen receptors. However, it does not address the anovulation and irregular menses associated with PCOS. It also lacks endometrial protection and carries teratogenic potential, necessitating additional contraceptive measures.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's symptoms, including irregular menstrual cycles, hirsutism, obesity, and ultrasound findings of bilaterally enlarged ovaries with multiple peripheral follicles, are consistent with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Combined estrogen-progestin oral contraceptive therapy is the preferred treatment for patients with PCOS who are not seeking pregnancy. It regulates menstrual cycles, provides endometrial protection against unopposed estrogen, and reduces androgen levels by increasing sex hormone-binding globulin production. This reduction in free testosterone levels alleviates hirsutism and other androgen-related symptoms. Additionally, the estrogen component suppresses luteinizing hormone secretion, reducing ovarian androgen production.

Key learning point: In women with PCOS who are not planning pregnancy, combined oral contraceptive pills are the first-line treatment for managing menstrual irregularities and hirsutism.

C) INCORRECT:

Clomiphene citrate induces ovulation by increasing gonadotropin release, which is beneficial for PCOS patients seeking fertility. However, this patient is not interested in pregnancy, making clomiphene less appropriate. It does not effectively manage menstrual irregularity or hyperandrogenism.

D) INCORRECT:

Metformin improves insulin sensitivity and can support ovulatory function, making it useful in PCOS patients with metabolic dysfunction or those seeking pregnancy. However, it does not effectively address hyperandrogenic symptoms like hirsutism or regulate menstrual cycles when used alone. The patient is not interested in pregnancy, so metformin's ovulation-promoting effects are less relevant.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman presents with irregular menstrual cycles, progressive coarse facial hair for the past year, and gradual weight gain. Her body mass index is 32 kg/m². Physical examination reveals increased terminal hair in a male-pattern distribution. Thyroid function and serum prolactin are normal (see lab result and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values


Testosterone
3.5 nmol/L
0.7 - 2.8 nmol/L


Pelvic ultrasound: Multiple small ovarian cysts
Which underlying endocrine mechanism best accounts for this patient’s clinical and laboratory findings?

choices.text: Excess adrenal androgen production due to congenital enzyme deficiency
Pituitary lactotroph adenoma causing decreased gonadotropin release
Elevated luteinizing hormone relative to follicle-stimulating hormone promoting ovarian androgen synthesis
Thyroid-stimulating hormone hypersecretion leading to altered gonadotropin regulation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia, due to enzyme deficiencies, leads to excess adrenal androgen production, often presenting with elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels. This condition typically presents earlier in life and may include signs of adrenal dysfunction, such as salt wasting. The presence of multiple ovarian cysts and elevated testosterone suggests an ovarian, not adrenal, source of androgen excess.

B) INCORRECT:

Pituitary lactotroph adenomas typically cause menstrual irregularities by increasing prolactin levels, which suppress gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH). This patient has normal prolactin levels, and the elevated testosterone and polycystic ovaries suggest ovarian hyperandrogenism, not a hypogonadal state from decreased gonadotropin release.

C) CORRECT:

Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is characterized by an increased luteinizing hormone (LH) to follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) ratio, leading to excess androgen production by ovarian theca cells. This results in hyperandrogenism, manifesting as hirsutism and menstrual irregularities.
